abstract: A federal judge in Houston on Wednesday threw out the conviction of Kevin A. Howard, the former chief financial officer for Enron‘s Broadband unit, citing a ruling in a similar case in which the jury’s verdict was vacated. The decision was based on a ruling in August by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, that essentially exonerates employees who provide so-called honest services while keeping with corporate goals and do not rob their employers of any money.

abstract: The Russian government on Wednesday tentatively approved two laws that would sharply restrict foreign ownership of oil and natural gas fields, putting in writing a growing practice there. One law bans foreign majority ownership of companies in the aerospace, military and nuclear power industries, while stating that all others should be open equally to Russian and foreign capital. The second law limits foreign ownership of specific oil and gas fields.
lead_paragraph: The Russian government on Wednesday tentatively approved two laws that would sharply restrict foreign ownership of oil and natural gas fields, putting in writing a growing practice there. One law bans foreign majority ownership of companies in the aerospace, military and nuclear power industries, while stating that all others should be open equally to Russian and foreign capital. The second law limits foreign ownership of specific oil and gas fields.

headline.main: Russia Moves to Restrict Foreign Ownership of Energy Fields

abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on Wednesday extended for one year a moratorium on considering nonfinancial companies’ applications to establish or acquire banks. The decision suspends applications from companies like Wal-Mart Stores, Home Depot and DaimlerChrysler, and gives Congress time to consider legislation that would prohibit them from running their own lending banks, called industrial loan corporations.

headline.main: Carlyle Smooths Out Deal for Philosophy

abstract: The chief executive of Overland Capital Group, a Boston private equity firm under federal investigation for its connection to groups accused of financing Islamic extremists, denied Wednesday that his company is linked to terrorism. “We do everything appropriately and by the book, and we adhere not just to the letter of the law but to the spirit of the law,” the executive, James M. Godec, told The Boston Globe. “I am extraordinarily cautious about this kind of stuff.”

Godec, told The Boston Globe. “I am extraordinarily cautious about this kind of stuff.”

headline.main: Head of Boston Buyout Shop Denies Ties to Terror

abstract: As speculation mounts that The Financial Times may go on the block, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal positioned the company as a possible bidder for the newspaper. Gordon Crovitz, publisher of The Journal, which is owned by Dow Jones, told The Guardian that the company would be interested in buying the Financial Times should its owner, Pearson, ever put it up for sale. “If the F.T. ever were to come on the market we would look at it,” he told The Guardian. “But so far Pearson has [maintained] it’s not for sale.”
lead_paragraph: As speculation mounts that The Financial Times may go on the block, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal positioned the company as a possible bidder for the newspaper. Gordon Crovitz, publisher of The Journal, which is owned by Dow Jones, told The Guardian that the company would be interested in buying the Financial Times should its owner, Pearson, ever put it up for sale. “If the F.T. ever were to come on the market we would look at it,” he told The Guardian. “But so far Pearson has [maintained] it’s not for sale.”

headline.main: Wall Street Journal Likes Looks of a Rival

abstract: Would bankers who took home part of last year’s juicy bonus pool be willing to trade it in for a sky-diving adventure on the company’s tab? Maybe not, but for entrepreneurs, the perk, not the cash bonus, is gaining popularity, The New York Times says. In a tight labor market where large employers can lure workers with bigger salaries and the opportunity to work for a known company, entrepreneurs said they could gain an edge by offering generous perks, which range from sky-diving to pet sitting and spa visits.

In a tight labor market where large employers can lure workers with bigger salaries and the opportunity to work for a known company, entrepreneurs said they could gain an edge by offering generous perks, which range from sky-diving to pet sitting and spa visits.

headline.main: The Rise of the Perk

abstract: Two prominent Republican senators renewed their criticism Wednesday of the way the Securities and Exchange Commission carried out its investigation into a major hedge fund, Pequot Capital Management. In separate speeches on the Senate floor, the senators, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, said the S.E.C. – which filed no charges against Pequot – had failed to aggressively follow up on investigative leads developed by the lawyer who led the inquiry, Gary J. Aguirre.
lead_paragraph: Two prominent Republican senators renewed their criticism Wednesday of the way the Securities and Exchange Commission carried out its investigation into a major hedge fund, Pequot Capital Management. Grassley of Iowa, said the S.E.C. – which filed no charges against Pequot – had failed to aggressively follow up on investigative leads developed by the lawyer who led the inquiry, Gary J. Aguirre.

headline.main: Senators Criticize S.E.C. on Pequot Inquiry

abstract: A harmonic convergence of near double-digit economic growth, a roaring bull market, and expansion-minded executives has set the stage for another year of high-volume initial public offering activity in India, says BusinessWeek. And this year could be a record-buster.

abstract: As pundits, voters and Washington insiders wonder whether former Vice President Al Gore will jump into the 2008 presidential race, The San Jose Mercury News discusses what it calls a “political problem” for Mr. Gore should he choose to run. The newspaper writes that Mr. Gore has become “enmeshed, and enriched, in Silicon Valley through his association with a close-knit elite that includes Apple‘s founder and chief executive Steven P. Jobs, Google‘s chief executive, Eric Schmidt, and a venture capitalist, John Doerr, a Google director.”

abstract: Tribune‘s largest shareholder, the Chandler family, on Wednesday extended the deadline on an offer for the Chicago-based media company, The Chicago Tribune reported. Talks are continuing between the special independent committee of the Tribune board considering options to maximize shareholder value and the Chandler family, which owns 20 percent of the company, the report said.
lead_paragraph: Tribune‘s largest shareholder, the Chandler family, on Wednesday extended the deadline on an offer for the Chicago-based media company, The Chicago Tribune reported. Talks are continuing between the special independent committee of the Tribune board considering options to maximize shareholder value and the Chandler family, which owns 20 percent of the company, the report said.

headline.main: Chandlers Said to Extend Deadline in Tribune Bid

abstract: The fallout from a four-year-old investigation into the mutual fund industry in the United States continues to haunt the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, after several former officials at the bank’s New York brokerage arm were accused Wednesday of taking part in an improper fund trading scheme. The Securities and Exchange Commission levied allegations against four officials, who it claimed collaborated with hedge funds to make deceptive trades. The S.E.C. also fined a former CIBC World Markets manager $100,000 as part of a settlement over allegations he repeatedly ignored warnings about his brokers.
lead_paragraph: The fallout from a four-year-old investigation into the mutual fund industry in the United States continues to haunt the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, after several former officials at the bank’s New York brokerage arm were accused Wednesday of taking part in an improper fund trading scheme. The Securities and Exchange Commission levied allegations against four officials, who it claimed collaborated with hedge funds to make deceptive trades. The S.E.C. also fined a former CIBC World Markets manager $100,000 as part of a settlement over allegations he repeatedly ignored warnings about his brokers.

headline.main: C.I.B.C. Executives Charged in Mutual-Fund Inquiry

abstract: The insurance broker Marsh & McLennan said on Thursday that it would sell its troubled money manager, Putnam Investments, to a unit of Power Financial of Canada for $3.9 billion. The sale price was in line with recent press reports, but toward the lower end of initial estimates of how much Putnam would fetch when Marsh & McLennan said in September that it was considering a sale.
lead_paragraph: The insurance broker Marsh & McLennan said on Thursday that it would sell its troubled money manager, Putnam Investments, to a unit of Power Financial of Canada for $3.9 billion. The sale price was in line with recent press reports, but toward the lower end of initial estimates of how much Putnam would fetch when Marsh & McLennan said in September that it was considering a sale.

headline.main: Power Announces $3.9 Billion Deal for Putnam

abstract: Deutsche Bank , Germany’s biggest bank, said fourth-quarter profit more than tripled, helped by lower taxes and higher revenue from trading stocks and bonds. Net income rose to 1.8 billion euros ($2.35 billion), or 3.55 euros a share, from 487 million euros, or 94 cents a share, a year earlier. Profit beat analysts’ estimates of 1.39 billion euros as the company’s tax rate unexpectedly fell to 22 percent from 31 percent in the third quarter. Revenue advanced 9 percent to 7.16 billion euros.
lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank , Germany’s biggest bank, said fourth-quarter profit more than tripled, helped by lower taxes and higher revenue from trading stocks and bonds. Net income rose to 1.8 billion euros ($2.35 billion), or 3.55 euros a share, from 487 million euros, or 94 cents a share, a year earlier. Profit beat analysts’ estimates of 1.39 billion euros as the company’s tax rate unexpectedly fell to 22 percent from 31 percent in the third quarter. Revenue advanced 9 percent to 7.16 billion euros.

headline.main: Deutsche’s Fourth-Quarter Profit Surges

abstract: JimmyJane, a startup that makes high-end sex toys, has raised $1.1 million in financing from a group of investors that includes an entity controlled by Tim Draper, the veteran venture capitalist, according to Private Equity Week.

abstract: The Jones Apparel Group has had conversations with investment bankers about a potential break-up of the company, including an initial public offering of the Barneys New York luxury department store chain, The New York Post reported. The company has hired Goldman Sachs and Citigroup to help it explore all possible options, short of an outright sale of the company, according to the report. Jones Apparel put itself up for sale last year, but eventually called off the auction as a result of disappointing bids.

Jones Apparel put itself up for sale last year, but eventually called off the auction as a result of disappointing bids.

headline.main: Is Barneys Headed to Market?

abstract: Time Warner‘s chief executive, Richard Parsons, told the Financial Times that splitting off Time Warner Cable into a separate company is a top priority this year, though when the cable unit’s shares will begin trading remains unclear. He also said he did not expect the new shares to be used to fund cable acquisitions right away. With the spinoff delayed by a ruling in the Adelphia Communications bankruptcy case, Time Warner is also exploring a traditional initial public offering for the cable unitl.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner‘s chief executive, Richard Parsons, told the Financial Times that splitting off Time Warner Cable into a separate company is a top priority this year, though when the cable unit’s shares will begin trading remains unclear. He also said he did not expect the new shares to be used to fund cable acquisitions right away. With the spinoff delayed by a ruling in the Adelphia Communications bankruptcy case, Time Warner is also exploring a traditional initial public offering for the cable unitl.

headline.main: Time Warner Chief Says Cable Spinoff Is Top Priority

abstract: Michael S. Dell has taken back the leadership of the computer company he founded, replacing Kevin B. Rollins after more than a year of mounting problems at Dell. The company announced Wednesday that Mr. Rollins had resigned as chief executive and as a director. Mr. Dell, who is the chairman, immediately assumed Mr. Rollins’s duties as well.
lead_paragraph: Michael S. Dell has taken back the leadership of the computer company he founded, replacing Kevin B. Rollins after more than a year of mounting problems at Dell. The company announced Wednesday that Mr. Rollins had resigned as chief executive and as a director. Mr. Dell, who is the chairman, immediately assumed Mr. Rollins’s duties as well.

headline.main: Dell’s Chief Is Replaced by Founder

abstract: Vornado Realty Trust said Thursday it had raised its offer to buy the Equity Office Properties Group to $56 a share in cash and stock, marking the latest escalation in an increasingly personal contest to acquire the largest office landlord in the United States. Vornado’s latest bid surpasses last week’s offer of $54 a share in cash, or $38.3 billion, from the private equity firm Blackstone Group. Blackstone has already raised its price once since announcing its bid for Equity Office in November. Whoever wins, the transaction will be the biggest buyout in history.
lead_paragraph: Vornado Realty Trust said Thursday it had raised its offer to buy the Equity Office Properties Group to $56 a share in cash and stock, marking the latest escalation in an increasingly personal contest to acquire the largest office landlord in the United States. Vornado’s latest bid surpasses last week’s offer of $54 a share in cash, or $38.3 billion, from the private equity firm Blackstone Group. Blackstone has already raised its price once since announcing its bid for Equity Office in November. Whoever wins, the transaction will be the biggest buyout in history.

headline.main: Vornado Raises the Stakes in Equity Office Showdown

abstract: The Tokyo Stock Exchange, which agreed this week to collaborate with the New York Stock Exchange, is discussing a potential alliance with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, an official at the Tokyo exchange said Thursday. “We are in negotiations for a possible alliance with the C.M.E., especially in the area of futures trading of Japan government bonds,” The spokesman, Toru Onoda, told The Associated Press.

abstract: Merrill Lynch won approval of a $40.3 million settlement of three lawsuits over claims it provided misleading analyst research about Internet companies. Judge John Keenan of United States District Court in New York on Wednesday approved settlements reached after investors appealed the 2003 dismissal of two of the cases. Judge Keenan also awarded $9 million to lawyers who represented almost 400,000 investors who sued.
lead_paragraph: Merrill Lynch won approval of a $40.3 million settlement of three lawsuits over claims it provided misleading analyst research about Internet companies. Judge John Keenan of United States District Court in New York on Wednesday approved settlements reached after investors appealed the 2003 dismissal of two of the cases. Judge Keenan also awarded $9 million to lawyers who represented almost 400,000 investors who sued.

headline.main: Court Approves Settlement of Merrill Analyst Suits

abstract: HSBC appointed Frank Slevin as its head of global banking, Asia-Pacific, a move aimed at building up its investment banking in the region. Mr. Slevin, who was formerly the chief operating officer of Citigroup’s Asia-Pacific investment-banking unit, will report to the heads of corporate and investment banking and markets and to the co-heads of global banking.

abstract: Lehman Brothers bought a 20 percent stake in a London hedge fund, the Spinnaker Capital Group on Wednesday, marking its latest move into hedge funds. Terms of the deal were not available, but The New York Post reported Lehman may have paid between $75 million and $100 million for the stake in Spinnaker, a $5.4 billion fund. The paper also said that Lehman plans to raise its stake in Spinnaker to 25 percent by year’s end.

The paper also said that Lehman plans to raise its stake in Spinnaker to 25 percent by year’s end.

headline.main: Lehman Takes Stake in London Hedge Fund

abstract: LVMH, the French conglomerate that owns luxury brands such as Louis Vuitton and Fendi, may be adding Aston Martin to its collection as well. MarketWatch said that the German trade publication Autobild was expected to report Friday that LVMH is set to buy Aston Martin, the British sports-car maker that is part of Ford Motor‘s Premium Automotive Group. A spokesman for the Premium Automotive Group told Dow Jones Newswires that the sale process for Aston Martin was “ongoing.”

abstract: Former New York City mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is getting support from some high-flying financiers as he considers whether to run for president in 2008. Data published on Wednesday by PoliticalMoneyLine.com show that contributors to Mr. Giuliani’s presidential exploratory committee, formed in November, include T. Boone Pickens, the Texas mogul who runs the hedge fund BP Capital Management; and Paul Tudor Jones II, the chairman of the hedge fund Tudor Investment Corporation. The fund also got money from Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor, filings show.

The fund also got money from Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor, filings show.

headline.main: Hedge Fund Moguls Back Giuliani’s Presidential Fund

abstract: Business leaders applauded nearly everything President Bush said Wednesday during his visit to Wall Street. An exception was his call for more accountability on executive pay, which was met with silence from the crowd of business leaders at Federal Hall National Memorial. The compensation of chief executives “should be based on their success at improving their companies and bringing value to their shareholders,” Mr. Bush said, adding that “America’s corporate boardrooms must step up to their responsibilities.”

abstract: Could initial public offerings rebound this year? Some hopeful private equity managers and venture capitalists seem to think so. There is, Rob Garver of CFO.com declares, “a growing feeling that the future may be 2007.” One reason is that startups are getting restless. “Going public is the goal,” David Spreng, a partner at Crescendo Ventures, told CFO.com. “When a C.E.O. is rallying the troops, he’s not planting his flag and telling everyone, ‘Let’s build this company so that we can sell it to a private-equity firm.'”

abstract: Wall Street loves a good breakup these days. Case in point: American Standard, whose shares soared 7 percent Thursday after the company said it would carve itself into three separate companies through a spinoff of its vehicle-control systems unit and a sale of its kitchen and bath fixtures business. With those divisions gone, American Standard would be left with its air-conditioning business, called Trane.

abstract: In the past five years or so, famed private equity firm Carlyle Group has transformed itself from a company that focused primarily on buying and selling defense companies that did business with governments, to one that now deals in a broad swath of alternative assets. The firm also cut ties with some of its high-profile political advisers, including George H.W. Bush and John Major. BusinessWeek takes a look at how — and why — the firm’s founders undertook this radical overhaul.

headline.main: Carlyle’s Great Experiment

abstract: Can an auction of a new type of security prove that stock options are not worth as much as financial models say they are – and therefore allow companies to report higher profits while handing out options to employees and executives? The Securities and Exchange Commission has given a tentative approval to one auction method, while warning that auditors should study the results of the auction before actually using the results in their financial statements.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has given a tentative approval to one auction method, while warning that auditors should study the results of the auction before actually using the results in their financial statements.

abstract: A federal judge in Texas has ruled that a widely used aggressive tax shelter was based on fake bank loans and is therefore not legitimate, giving an unexpected boost to federal prosecutors overseeing a widening criminal investigation into tax shelters. The shelter, known as Blips, plays a central role in the criminal inquiry of Deutsche Bank over questionable tax shelters and in the pending criminal trial in federal court in Manhattan of 16 former employees of the accounting firm KPMG and two outsiders.

abstract: The former head of an Idaho hedge fund, Wood River Capital Management, has been indicted on charges that he engaged in securities fraud that cost investors $88 million, prosecutors said Thursday. The United States attorney’s office in Manhattan said John H. Whittier, Wood River’s majority shareholder and principal executive, was charged with securities fraud and failure to disclose a beneficial interest in a publicly traded security. Mr. Whittier is expected to be arraigned next week.

Whittier, Wood River’s majority shareholder and principal executive, was charged with securities fraud and failure to disclose a beneficial interest in a publicly traded security. Mr. Whittier is expected to be arraigned next week.

headline.main: Hedge Fund Officer Is Accused of Fraud

abstract: Coca-Cola said Thursday that it had agreed to buy Fuze Beverage to add more juice, tea and energy drinks in an effort to catch up with PepsiCo. Coca-Cola gains a half-dozen new products, including Fuze Tea, NOS energy drinks and Fuze Slenderize, which has chromium and amino acids that Fuze says help promote weight loss.
lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola said Thursday that it had agreed to buy Fuze Beverage to add more juice, tea and energy drinks in an effort to catch up with PepsiCo. headline.main: Coca-Cola Swallows Fuze Beverage

abstract: Lone Star Funds, the United States buyout firm whose sale of Korea Exchange Bank was blocked by a corruption investigation, will collect $445 million in dividends from the bank. Korea Exchange will pay 1,000 won ($1.10) a share, it said in a regulatory filing to the stock exchange Thursday. Lone Star, based in Dallas, controls 64.6 percent of the bank. Lone Star halted a $6.8 billion sale of the bank because of an investigation by prosecutors into its original acquisition of Korea Exchange four years ago for $1.49 billion. The dividend is the first in 10 years by the bank, South Korea’s fifth-largest.

headline.main: Big Dividend for Lone Star

abstract: Consolidation in Europe’s energy sector ramped up yesterday, as two $31 billion deals loomed on the horizon. Dutch utilities Essent and Nuon unveiled an agreement to create a 24 billion euro ($31 billion) energy giant that will rank among Europe’s top 10. The new company, to be called EssentNuon, will have 12 billion euros in sales and have a 20,000-strong work force in the Netherlands, Belgium and Germany and supply 5 million customers. Both firms are owned by local governments, and ownership of the new entity will be split 55 percent to 45 percent in Essent’s favor.

The new company, to be called EssentNuon, will have 12 billion euros in sales and have a 20,000-strong work force in the Netherlands, Belgium and Germany and supply 5 million customers. Both firms are owned by local governments, and ownership of the new entity will be split 55 percent to 45 percent in Essent’s favor.

headline.main: 2 Megadeals Warm Europe’s Energy Sector

abstract: Hospira, a hospital products maker, said Thursday that it had completed the $2.1 billion acquisition of Mayne Pharma Limited, an Australian maker of generic cancer medicines and other specialized injectable drugs. Hospira, based in Lake Forest, Ill., is already a U.S. leader in injectable drugs and intravenous solutions used primarily in hospitals. With its purchase of Mayne Pharma, Hospira adds a significant global presence, doubling international sales to account for nearly 30 percent of the company’s total sales.

abstract: British construction group Balfour Beatty said yesterday it was buying U.S. rival Centex Construction for $362 million in cash. The company, part of America’s fourth-biggest housebuilder, Centex, specializes in military housing with an order book worth $5.6 billion.

abstract: Former Enron prosecutor Kathy Ruemmler has joined the law firm of Latham & Watkins in Washington, D.C., confirming speculation that she would follow some of her former colleagues into private practice — and a higher income bracket. Ms. Ruemmler was one of three Assistant U.S. Attorneys who took leading roles in the 2004 Enron Nigerian barge case and the criminal trial of former Enron executives Jeffrey Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay last year. The move again puts her in the same office as her ex-boss, former Enron Task Force chief Sean Berkowitz, who joined Latham in November.

abstract: In what can’t possibly be music to Corus shareholders’ ears, Indian steel magnate Ratan Tata has said he would have been prepared to pay even more to clinch control of the Anglo-Dutch steelmaker. In an interview with The Times Of India today, the chairman of Tata group said: “Let me put it this way. At 608 pence ($11.97), we hadn’t reached the limit we had set ourselves.”

Sainsbury. Sainsbury shares soared as much as 18 percent Friday, giving the London-based company a market value of 8.8 billion pounds ($17.3 billion).

abstract: In a highly unusual move, RAB Capital, one of London’s leading hedge funds, is demanding “money back guarantees” before it invests in mining companies. The Telegraph reported that RAB, which is one of natural resources sector’s leading investors, recently inked a deal with Energy Capital to invest 500,000 pounds in the shell company.

abstract: Equity Office Properties Trust, the office landlord at the center of a takeover battle, on Friday reaffirmed its support for a $38.3 billion, all-cash bid from private equity firm Blackstone Group, saying it was less risky for shareholders than a $41 billion cash-and-stock offer from Vornado Realty Trust. Equity Office also said a vote on Blackstone’s offer will probably take place Feb. 7, two days later than previously planned, to give shareholders time to review new information about the bid.
lead_paragraph: Equity Office Properties Trust, the office landlord at the center of a takeover battle, on Friday reaffirmed its support for a $38.3 billion, all-cash bid from private equity firm Blackstone Group, saying it was less risky for shareholders than a $41 billion cash-and-stock offer from Vornado Realty Trust. Equity Office also said a vote on Blackstone’s offer will probably take place Feb. 7, two days later than previously planned, to give shareholders time to review new information about the bid.

headline.main: Equity Office Board Supports Blackstone Offer

abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission mishandled its inquiry into suspect trades by a prominent hedge fund, then may have tried to cover up those mistakes after its chief investigator on the case complained, according to an interim Senate report released Thursday. The report, released by the former chairmen of the Senate Judiciary and Finance Committees, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, also asked the S.E.C. or the Justice Department to consider investigating whether false testimony was given to S.E.C. officials who examined the hedge fund, Pequot Capital Management.

abstract: Cinemark Holdings, which owns 392 cinemas in the U.S. and Latin America, filed to sell shares in an initial public offering valued at about $400 million and use the proceeds to pay back debt. The company, which is controlled by Madison Dearborn Partners, was created through the October merger of Cinemark USA and Century Theatres. Cinemark plans to list on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol CNK.

abstract: A former information technology consultant for Morgan Stanley pleaded guilty in federal court late Wednesday to stealing data on the investment bank’s hedge fund clients, The New York Post reported. Ira Chilowitz, 44, faces a maximum of 26 years in prison and an $850,000 fine on charges of conspiracy, theft of trade secrets and other crimes. In court, Mr. Chilowitz admitted that he and an unnamed co-conspirator had set up their own business advising hedge funds on how to negotiate the fees investment banks charge.

In court, Mr. Chilowitz admitted that he and an unnamed co-conspirator had set up their own business advising hedge funds on how to negotiate the fees investment banks charge.

abstract: Hearst has recorded $330 million in losses in its investment in the San Francisco Chronicle and attempted to sell the newspaper to MediaNews Group, according to court documents made public Thursday in a media antitrust case. Terms of the 2005 proposal were not revealed. But MediaNews did not offer enough, so no deal was made, James Asher, Hearst’s chief legal officer, said in the documents. The New York-based publisher acquired the Chronicle for $660 million in 2000.

The New York-based publisher acquired the Chronicle for $660 million in 2000.

headline.main: Hearst Tried to Sell Chronicle

abstract: It is not so surprising that some of the most-expensive hedge funds — as measured by the fees they charge — can deliver below-average returns. After all, anyone can have a bad year (or two). The more remarkable part about Financial News’ recent analysis of hedge funds with high fees is the suggestion that investors, who are mainly institutions and wealthy individuals, sometimes intentionally avoid funds that charge lower fees, preferring the cachet of a top-dollar fund even if its recent performance is lackluster.

abstract: The family that controls the The New York Times Company is withdrawing most of its assets from the custody of Morgan Stanley. The decision by the Sulzberger family, which a spokeswoman for the Times Company confirmed, comes as the Times Company is fighting a proposal by a Morgan Stanley fund manager that would allow shareholders to vote on whether to end the company’s two-tier stock structure and make it more vulnerable to a takeover.

abstract: Magnum Global Investments is a former client of Pirate Capital, a Connecticut-based hedge fund. According to a lawsuit filed by Magnum, Pirate reneged on its promise to pay for steering it $28 million in investments. David Friedland, Magnum’s president, tells Bloomberg News that his firm’s relationship with Thomas Hudson, the chief Pirate, “got pretty ugly.” If, he said, “we’d known this was the kind of character he had, we wouldn’t have invested.”

abstract: TheStreet has added a feature to Stockpickr, its automatic stock-recommendation site: system trades of the day. But we found the most interesting to be the Takeover Targets System. It rebalances every month, generating a new set of stocks that are most likely to be acquisition candidates.

abstract: Despite the enthusiasm of analysts and investors, the rumored acquisition of Bristol-Myers Squibb by Paris-based Sanofi-Aventis is probably a bad idea in the long term, writes Forbes’ Matthew Herper. abstract: Another major battle has surfaced in the commercial real estate market, this time over the ailing mall developer Mills Corporation. Confirming a report in The New York Times, the Simon Property Group, the nation’s largest mall developer, and Farallon Capital Management, a $26 billion hedge fund, on Monday announced a $1.56 billion cash bid for Mills, challenging its already agreed-upon deal to be sold for $1.4 billion to Brookfield Capital Management.
lead_paragraph: Another major battle has surfaced in the commercial real estate market, this time over the ailing mall developer Mills Corporation. headline.main: New Suitor Ignites Battle for Ailing Mills Corporation

abstract: A court date is not the only thing marked on the spring calendar of Conrad M. Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International. Nixon, “The Invincible Quest: The Life of Richard Milhous Nixon,” to be published in May.

abstract: When James R. Houghton began a second stint as chief executive at Corning in 2002, the company was reeling. The first thing he did, Mr. Houghton told The New York Times, was “to see if there was somebody I should shoot.” Now Michael S. Dell will be taking aim. This week he reclaimed the chief executive job that he had handed over to Kevin B. Rollins two years ago, resuming day-to-day leadership of the computer company he founded.

This week he reclaimed the chief executive job that he had handed over to Kevin B. Rollins two years ago, resuming day-to-day leadership of the computer company he founded.

headline.main: 2nd Acts in the Executive Suite

abstract: A federal jury rejected a former Coca-Cola secretary’s claim that she was duped by two accomplices and convicted her on Friday of conspiring to steal trade secrets from the world’s largest beverage maker in an effort to sell them to its rival, Pepsi. The former secretary, Joya Williams, showed no visible reaction when the verdict was announced. She remains free on bond, pending sentencing.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury rejected a former Coca-Cola secretary’s claim that she was duped by two accomplices and convicted her on Friday of conspiring to steal trade secrets from the world’s largest beverage maker in an effort to sell them to its rival, Pepsi. headline.main: Ex-Secretary at Coke Guilty of Trade-Secrets Theft

abstract: In a sign of the growing tension between old-line media and the new Internet behemoths, Viacom, the parent company of MTV and Comedy Central, demanded on Friday that YouTube, the video-sharing Web site owned by Google, remove more than 100,000 clips of its programming.
lead_paragraph: In a sign of the growing tension between old-line media and the new Internet behemoths, Viacom, the parent company of MTV and Comedy Central, demanded on Friday that YouTube, the video-sharing Web site owned by Google, remove more than 100,000 clips of its programming.

headline.main: YouTube, Viacom and Some Unfriendly Dealmaking

abstract: Canada’s Brookfield Asset Management and the founders of Australia’s Multiplex have approached the $3 billion construction firm about a possible takeover as it struggles with the troubled Wembley stadium project in London. No value for any bid was given, but analysts told Reuters that around 5 Australian dollars a share might be the most offered for Multiplex, which has a market capitalization of 4.04 billion Australian dollars ($3 billion). Shares in Multiplex rose 8 percent to 4.91 Australian dollars on news of the talks.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s Brookfield Asset Management and the founders of Australia’s Multiplex have approached the $3 billion construction firm about a possible takeover as it struggles with the troubled Wembley stadium project in London. Shares in Multiplex rose 8 percent to 4.91 Australian dollars on news of the talks.

headline.main: Australia’s Multiplex Elicits Interest from Consortium

abstract: Sumner Redstone, chairman of the CBS Corporation and Viacom, settled a lawsuit with his son, according to The Wall Street Journal. The lawsuit, filed last year in the Circuit Court of Maryland for Baltimore, claimed that Mr. Redstone had tried to “freeze out” his son, Brent Redstone, from National Amusements, the family firm that holds a controlling stake in Viacom and CBS.
lead_paragraph: Sumner Redstone, chairman of the CBS Corporation and Viacom, settled a lawsuit with his son, according to The Wall Street Journal. abstract: A South Korean court on Monday found the head of the Hyundai Motor Group, the world’s No.6 auto maker, guilty of breach of trust and embezzling company funds. The country’s prosecutors last month demanded a six-year jail term for the executive, Chung Mong-koo, who was the group’s chairman.
lead_paragraph: A South Korean court on Monday found the head of the Hyundai Motor Group, the world’s No.6 auto maker, guilty of breach of trust and embezzling company funds. headline.main: Hyundai Head Found Guilty by South Korean Court

abstract: As the merger and acquisition boom rages on, Goldman Sachs, top banker to blue-chip companies, is eyeing middle-market deals as a way to further increase its banking fees, which hit record levels last year. In this case, says Reuters, middle market means companies ranging from $500 million to $2 billion in market value.

abstract: A corruption affair that has shaken the German industrial conglomerate Siemens has spread to the United States with investigations by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission. “The U.S. Department of Justice is conducting an investigation of possible criminal violations of U.S. law by Siemens in connection with these matters,” Siemens said in its first-quarter financial report. The company is being investigated by German prosecutors for suspected bribery related to telecoms contracts.

The company is being investigated by German prosecutors for suspected bribery related to telecoms contracts.

headline.main: Corruption Charges Follow Siemens to the U.S.

abstract: The board of Endesa will meet Tuesday to consider its response to a 41 billion euro ($53 billion) bid by E.ON of Germany in what should mark the final stage of the battle for control of Endesa, Spain’s largest electricity group. The Financial Times reported that directors are likely to recommend the 38.75-euro-a-share offer, which is 41 percent higher than the original bid presented by E.ON almost a year ago
lead_paragraph: The board of Endesa will meet Tuesday to consider its response to a 41 billion euro ($53 billion) bid by E.ON of Germany in what should mark the final stage of the battle for control of Endesa, Spain’s largest electricity group. The Financial Times reported that directors are likely to recommend the 38.75-euro-a-share offer, which is 41 percent higher than the original bid presented by E.ON almost a year ago

headline.main: Endesa Board Likely to Accept E.ON Offer, Report Says

abstract: The private equity firm Texas Pacific Group may try to elbow in on a possible deal for the British supermarket giant J. Sainsbury and is working on building a consortium, the Financial Times reported. The rival buyout shops CVC, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Blackstone said on Friday they were in the early stages of assessing a bid for Sainsbury, Britain’s third-largest supermarket owner, in what would be Europe’s biggest leveraged buyout.
lead_paragraph: The private equity firm Texas Pacific Group may try to elbow in on a possible deal for the British supermarket giant J. headline.main: Texas Pacific May Also Like the Looks of Europe’s Biggest L.B.O.

abstract: Overstock.com, whose chief executive has been roundly criticized for his crusade against naked short selling and what he claims is a vast conspiracy to bring down the stock of his company, filed a $3.5 billion lawsuit in California state court Friday accusing 10 of the largest securities firms in the nation of participating in a “massive, illegal stock market manipulation scheme” to distort the retailer’s stock.
lead_paragraph: Overstock.com, whose chief executive has been roundly criticized for his crusade against naked short selling and what he claims is a vast conspiracy to bring down the stock of his company, filed a $3.5 billion lawsuit in California state court Friday accusing 10 of the largest securities firms in the nation of participating in a “massive, illegal stock market manipulation scheme” to distort the retailer’s stock.

headline.main: Overstock Takes Banks to Court Over Short Selling

abstract: British estate agency firm Countrywide is in talks to be acquired by the Apollo Management buyout group of the United States, according to press reports. The Sunday Times reported that Apollo was planning a bid for Countrywide worth about 950 million pounds ($1.9 billion), and Reuters said the targeted firm was likely to put out a statement confirming the discussions on Monday.
lead_paragraph: British estate agency firm Countrywide is in talks to be acquired by the Apollo Management buyout group of the United States, according to press reports. headline.main: Apollo May Buy British Real Estate Firm, Reports Say

abstract: Paul Allen, the Microsoft co-founder and Seattle-area billionaire, has agreed to buy back the Rose Garden Arena in Portland that he previously owned. Mr. Allen is making the acquisition through his investment vehicle, Vulcan. As part of the agreement, a subsidiary of Vulcan plans to purchase Portland Arena Management, which has held the notes to the Rose Garden since Mr. Allen put the facility into bankruptcy about three years ago.
lead_paragraph: Paul Allen, the Microsoft co-founder and Seattle-area billionaire, has agreed to buy back the Rose Garden Arena in Portland that he previously owned. Mr. Allen is making the acquisition through his investment vehicle, Vulcan. As part of the agreement, a subsidiary of Vulcan plans to purchase Portland Arena Management, which has held the notes to the Rose Garden since Mr. Allen put the facility into bankruptcy about three years ago.

headline.main: Paul Allen Takes Back Rose Garden

abstract: TowerBrook Capital Partners has agreed to buy Jimmy Choo, whose shoes are worn by celebrities including Jennifer Lopez, for 185 million pounds ($364 million). TowerBrook, the buyout firm spun off from George Soros’s fund management business, and Jimmy Choo’s management, including its founder, Tamara Mellon, and chief executive, Robert Bensoussan, will buy the company from Lion Capital.
lead_paragraph: TowerBrook Capital Partners has agreed to buy Jimmy Choo, whose shoes are worn by celebrities including Jennifer Lopez, for 185 million pounds ($364 million). headline.main: Jimmy Choo Sold for $364 Million

abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took his message that New York City is losing its edge as a global financial center to London on Sunday, where he contrasted the British system of regulating financial markets with that of the United States. The mayor met with Sir Callum McCarthy, chairman of the Financial Services Authority, which regulates the banking, securities, insurance and investment industries in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. headline.main: Bloomberg Takes His Message to London

abstract: Barratt Developments, the largest homebuilder in Britain, agreed to buy Wilson Bowden for 2.2 billion pounds ($4.32 billion) in what Bloomberg News said is the biggest-ever takeover of a British housing developer. Barratt, based in Tyne, said it would will pay 2,257 pence in cash and stock for each Wilson share. That’s 23 percent higher than Wilson’s close on Nov. 24, the last day of trading before the company put itself up for sale.
lead_paragraph: Barratt Developments, the largest homebuilder in Britain, agreed to buy Wilson Bowden for 2.2 billion pounds ($4.32 billion) in what Bloomberg News said is the biggest-ever takeover of a British housing developer. Barratt, based in Tyne, said it would will pay 2,257 pence in cash and stock for each Wilson share. That’s 23 percent higher than Wilson’s close on Nov. 24, the last day of trading before the company put itself up for sale.

headline.main: British Homebuilder Buys Developer in Record Deal

abstract: Merrill Lynch hired Margaret Ren, a former Citigroup executive, as chairman of China investment banking after regulators in the United States cleared her of wrongdoing in a 2003 initial public offering. Ms. Ren, the daughter-in-law of former Chinese Premier Zhao Ziyang, will report to the China region chairman, Liu Erh-fei and the Asia banking head, Sheldon Trainor.
lead_paragraph: Merrill Lynch hired Margaret Ren, a former Citigroup executive, as chairman of China investment banking after regulators in the United States cleared her of wrongdoing in a 2003 initial public offering. Ms. Ren, the daughter-in-law of former Chinese Premier Zhao Ziyang, will report to the China region chairman, Liu Erh-fei and the Asia banking head, Sheldon Trainor.

headline.main: Merrill Hires Former Citigroup Exec for China

abstract: Hedge funds will not see a richer payday after two financial investors for Techem, a German utility metering group, abandoned their 1.4 billion euro ($1.8 billion) bid on Friday. The bidders, the Macquarie Bank of Australia and the private equity shop BC Partners of Boston, retreated after they failed to win commitments for 70.5 percent of Techem’s stock. The announcement comes after weeks of press reports that hedge funds, including Elliott Associates of New York, which reportedly now owns 10 percent of the group, had snapped up Techem shares, hoping for a higher bid.
lead_paragraph: Hedge funds will not see a richer payday after two financial investors for Techem, a German utility metering group, abandoned their 1.4 billion euro ($1.8 billion) bid on Friday. The bidders, the Macquarie Bank of Australia and the private equity shop BC Partners of Boston, retreated after they failed to win commitments for 70.5 percent of Techem’s stock. The announcement comes after weeks of press reports that hedge funds, including Elliott Associates of New York, which reportedly now owns 10 percent of the group, had snapped up Techem shares, hoping for a higher bid.

headline.main: Outcome of Techem Deal May Disappoint Hedge Funds

abstract: State Street agreed to buy Investors Financial Services in a stock transaction valued at about $4.5 billion. Investors Financial holders will receive 0.906 share of State Street for each of their shares, State Street said.
lead_paragraph: State Street agreed to buy Investors Financial Services in a stock transaction valued at about $4.5 billion. Investors Financial holders will receive 0.906 share of State Street for each of their shares, State Street said.

headline.main: State Street Takes Investors Financial for $4.5 Billion

abstract: Triad Hospitals, which runs 54 hospitals and 13 ambulatory surgery centers across the United States, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by a private equity firm, CCMP Capital Advisors, and the buyout arm of Goldman Sachs. Triad, spun off from the hospital chain HCA in 1999, valued the deal at $6.4 billion, including $1.7 billion in assumed debt. Some analysts have considered Triad a potential buyout candidate since HCA agreed to go private in a $33 billion transaction last year.
lead_paragraph: Triad Hospitals, which runs 54 hospitals and 13 ambulatory surgery centers across the United States, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by a private equity firm, CCMP Capital Advisors, and the buyout arm of Goldman Sachs. Some analysts have considered Triad a potential buyout candidate since HCA agreed to go private in a $33 billion transaction last year.

headline.main: Private Equity Firms to Buy Triad Hospitals

abstract: Last year’s $2-billion-plus funds from Oak Investment Partners and New Enterprise Associates underscore how venture firms have been raising larger investment pools and targeting more established companies, BusinessWeek reports.
lead_paragraph: Last year’s $2-billion-plus funds from Oak Investment Partners and New Enterprise Associates underscore how venture firms have been raising larger investment pools and targeting more established companies, BusinessWeek reports.

headline.main: Venture Funds Think Big

abstract: Today’s wave of buyouts reminds many of the 1980s, the last great age of highflying takeovers. But a small investment bank’s parties may be drawing a different page from the Predators’ Ball era. The New York Post highlights Roth Capital Management, a small-cap underwriter whose pricey bashes have included rappers like Ludacris and exotic entertainment like topless models painted with the ticker symbols of Roth Capital’s clients. In an age in which Wall Street firms still host big-ticket celebrations but have shunned anything that smacks of a potential lawsuit, the Post says, Roth is the exception to the rule.

In an age in which Wall Street firms still host big-ticket celebrations but have shunned anything that smacks of a potential lawsuit, the Post says, Roth is the exception to the rule.

headline.main: A Predators’ Ball for a New Age

abstract: One of London’s most recognizable skyscrapers was sold Monday for 600 million pounds ($1.18 billion) in a deal that could kick off a wave of high-priced British commercial real estate sales. Swiss Reinsurance said that it would sell its London headquarters, the 40-story glass skyscraper nicknamed “The Gherkin,” to the real estate comapny IVG Immobilien and the investment bank Evans Randall. The deal, which is expected to close in February, may set a record for a London office building, the Telegraph said.

The deal, which is expected to close in February, may set a record for a London office building, the Telegraph said.

headline.main: London’s ‘Pickle’ Sold as Real Estate Heats Up

abstract: Brookfield Asset Management will acquire Longview Fibre, a paper and container maker, for $2.15 billion including debt. The Canadian real-estate firm will pay $24.75 a share, or an 18 percent premium to Longview’s closing price Friday. Through the deal, Brookfield will gain 588,000 acres of timberland in the Pacific Northwest.
lead_paragraph: Brookfield Asset Management will acquire Longview Fibre, a paper and container maker, for $2.15 billion including debt. The Canadian real-estate firm will pay $24.75 a share, or an 18 percent premium to Longview’s closing price Friday. Through the deal, Brookfield will gain 588,000 acres of timberland in the Pacific Northwest.

headline.main: Brookfield to Acquire Paper Maker for $2.15 Billion

abstract: Credit Suisse said Monday that it hired Michael D. Ryan, a former managing director at Goldman Sachs, as head of securities for its investment banking division. Mr. Ryan will join Credit Suisse’s New York office some time “midyear,” Credit Suisse said. He will oversee Credit Suisse’s global securities businesses and serve on the management committee of its investment banking group. At Goldman Sachs, Mr. Ryan had been co-head of global equities.
lead_paragraph: Credit Suisse said Monday that it hired Michael D. Ryan, a former managing director at Goldman Sachs, as head of securities for its investment banking division. headline.main: Revolving Door: Credit Suisse, C.E. Unterberg

abstract: Sales of music — both compact discs and downloads — are off to a weak start this year. So weak that Richard Greenfield, a media analyst at Pali Research, said Monday that total 2007 sales are likely to be even worse than he had previously expected (and he had expected them to be pretty bad). With such gloomy thoughts in mind, Mr. Greenfield cut his rating on shares of the Warner Music Group, the label whose artists include the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Madonna, to “sell.” He also suggested that a merger between Warner, which is backed by private investors including Edgar Bronfman Jr., and EMI of the United Kingdom looks increasingly unlikely.
lead_paragraph: Sales of music — both compact discs and downloads — are off to a weak start this year. abstract: As part of its return to the buyout business, Morgan Stanley plans to raise $6 billion or more for its latest private equity fund, Financial News Online reported, citing undisclosed “sources close to the bank.” In September, the firm announced that it was creating a private equity group within its asset management division, but Morgan Stanley has stayed fairly quiet on the effort since then. Three years ago, Morgan Stanley spun off its private equity business as Metalmark Capital.
lead_paragraph: As part of its return to the buyout business, Morgan Stanley plans to raise $6 billion or more for its latest private equity fund, Financial News Online reported, citing undisclosed “sources close to the bank.” In September, the firm announced that it was creating a private equity group within its asset management division, but Morgan Stanley has stayed fairly quiet on the effort since then. Three years ago, Morgan Stanley spun off its private equity business as Metalmark Capital.

headline.main: Morgan Stanley Said to Aim for $6 Billion Buyout Fund

abstract: It seems everyone wants a piece of the buyout boom. As private equity firms continue to spend billions of dollars to acquire public companies, M&C Saatchi, the advertising group, is creating an agency to serve the businesses they buy. Why would private-equity-backed companies advertise any differently than anyone else? The theory, according to Reuters’ article on the new firm, goes like this: To maximize their profits, buyout shops need to turn around their investments quickly. So they need to act faster to burnish their brands.
lead_paragraph: It seems everyone wants a piece of the buyout boom. As private equity firms continue to spend billions of dollars to acquire public companies, M&C Saatchi, the advertising group, is creating an agency to serve the businesses they buy. Why would private-equity-backed companies advertise any differently than anyone else? The theory, according to Reuters’ article on the new firm, goes like this: To maximize their profits, buyout shops need to turn around their investments quickly. So they need to act faster to burnish their brands.

headline.main: Advertising at the Speed of Private Equity

abstract: After placing a big bet on the beaten-down auto-parts business in October, Carl C. Icahn is doubling down. Mr. Icahn, who recently spent $200 million to increase his stake in Lear  to nearly 16 percent, has offered to acquire the entire company, Lear said in a news release early Monday. American Real Estate Partners, which Mr. Icahn controls, will offer $36 a share in cash for Lear, valuing the auto-parts maker at about $2.4 billion based on the number of shares outstanding on Nov. 3. The offer was about 4 percent more than Lear’s closing price of $34.67 on Friday.
lead_paragraph: After placing a big bet on the beaten-down auto-parts business in October, Carl C. Icahn is doubling down. American Real Estate Partners, which Mr. Icahn controls, will offer $36 a share in cash for Lear, valuing the auto-parts maker at about $2.4 billion based on the number of shares outstanding on Nov. 3. The offer was about 4 percent more than Lear’s closing price of $34.67 on Friday.

abstract: Brookfield Asset Management of Toronto said it would buy Longview Fibre, a specialty paper and packaging company, for $1.6 billion. Longview has a pulp and paper mill in Longview, Wash., and 15 corrugated-container plants, but its chief asset for Brookfield appears to be its 588,000 acres of woodlands in Washington and Oregon. They will join other timberlands owned by Brookfield, including 635,000 acres in British Columbia it bought from Weyerhaeuser in 2005. As part of the Longview deal, Brookfield will also assume about $550,000 in debt. Longview put itself up for sale in 2006 after rejecting a $1.33 billion bid from two private equity firms.

abstract: A London office tower known as the Gherkin was bought by IVG Immobilien, a German property company, and Evans Randall Investment Management, a British investment bank, for £600 million ($1.2 billion), a record for a building in the city’s main financial district. The Swiss Reinsurance Company, the tower’s owner, said it would remain the principal tenant in the 41-story building. Swiss Re, which is based in Zurich, will book a profit of £250 million ($500 million) from the sale. The Gherkin was designed by Norman Foster, winner of the Pritzker Prize, and opened in 2004. The tower, formally known as 30 St. Mary Axe, is “a genuine landmark with excellent long-term letting prospects,” IVG said.

abstract: The oneupmanship continued early Tuesday in the largest leveraged buyout ever. The Blackstone Group, a private equity firm, raised its offer to acquire Equity Office Properties, the real estate investment trust, to $55.50 a share, increasing the value of the transaction to about $39 billion, Equity Office said shortly after 1 a.m. Tuesday. Equity Office said the latest Blackstone offer had been unanimously approved by its board, which is led by the founder, Samuel Zell.
lead_paragraph: The oneupmanship continued early Tuesday in the largest leveraged buyout ever. The Blackstone Group, a private equity firm, raised its offer to acquire Equity Office Properties, the real estate investment trust, to $55.50 a share, increasing the value of the transaction to about $39 billion, Equity Office said shortly after 1 a.m. Tuesday. Equity Office said the latest Blackstone offer had been unanimously approved by its board, which is led by the founder, Samuel Zell.

headline.main: Blackstone Raises Equity Office Bid to $39 Billion

abstract: Home Depot reached an agreement Monday night with a large shareholder, Relational Investors, that will prevent a proxy fight over the company’s strategy. But the move could increase pressure on Home Depot to sell one of its units. Under the terms of the agreement, Relational, a San Diego investment fund, will receive a seat on the company’s board and four directors involved in hiring Robert L. Nardelli, the recently dismissed chief executive, will leave the board in 2008. A founder of Relational, David H. Batchelder, will join the Home Depot board on Feb. 22, and the investment fund will drop its proxy challenge, the two companies said in a joint statement.

Nardelli, the recently dismissed chief executive, will leave the board in 2008. A founder of Relational, David H. Batchelder, will join the Home Depot board on Feb. 22, and the investment fund will drop its proxy challenge, the two companies said in a joint statement.

headline.main: As Home Depot Settles Proxy Fight, Sale Talk Lingers

abstract: Many in India, which gained independence from Britain in 1947, are discovering that it is far more appealing to belong to a nation doing the takeovers rather than being taken over. Much of India erupted with jubilation last week when the Tata Group, an Indian conglomerate, won the bidding for the Corus Group, the British-Dutch steel company, with an $11.3 billion offer, the largest acquisition ever by an Indian company.
lead_paragraph: Many in India, which gained independence from Britain in 1947, are discovering that it is far more appealing to belong to a nation doing the takeovers rather than being taken over. Much of India erupted with jubilation last week when the Tata Group, an Indian conglomerate, won the bidding for the Corus Group, the British-Dutch steel company, with an $11.3 billion offer, the largest acquisition ever by an Indian company.

headline.main: India Is Reveling in Being the Buyer

abstract: The chairman of Hyundai Motor, sentenced on Monday to three years in prison for embezzling corporate funds, will continue to run the corporation while his case is appealed. The presiding judge, Kim Dong-oh, said that the chairman, Chung Mong-koo, committed a “clearly criminal act” by raising and using “a large-scale secretive fund” that “greatly undermines the transparency and soundness of business management and has many adverse effects on our business culture.”
lead_paragraph: The chairman of Hyundai Motor, sentenced on Monday to three years in prison for embezzling corporate funds, will continue to run the corporation while his case is appealed. The presiding judge, Kim Dong-oh, said that the chairman, Chung Mong-koo, committed a “clearly criminal act” by raising and using “a large-scale secretive fund” that “greatly undermines the transparency and soundness of business management and has many adverse effects on our business culture.”

headline.main: Hyundai Chief, Awaiting Appeal, to Stay on Job

abstract: Russian prosecutors brought new charges Monday against the imprisoned founder of the Yukos oil company and one of his business partners, opening a new line of legal attack against a Kremlin opponent. The former executive, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, and his partner, Platon A. Lebedev, were charged with embezzlement and money laundering, which his lawyers said together could carry prison sentences of 15 years.
lead_paragraph: Russian prosecutors brought new charges Monday against the imprisoned founder of the Yukos oil company and one of his business partners, opening a new line of legal attack against a Kremlin opponent. The former executive, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, and his partner, Platon A. Lebedev, were charged with embezzlement and money laundering, which his lawyers said together could carry prison sentences of 15 years.

headline.main: New Charges in Russia Against Oil Executives

abstract: Two investment banks, Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse, asked a federal appeals court on Monday to end a class-action lawsuit by Enron investors seeking $40 billion that they lost when the energy trader collapsed in 2001. The banks argued that a Houston judge was wrong to allow Enron investors to sue as a group and contended that they could not be sued because they did not participate directly in the accounting fraud that led to Enron’s bankruptcy. The investors argued the court could address only whether the plaintiffs could sue as a group. Trial is set for April in Houston.
lead_paragraph: Two investment banks, Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse, asked a federal appeals court on Monday to end a class-action lawsuit by Enron investors seeking $40 billion that they lost when the energy trader collapsed in 2001. The banks argued that a Houston judge was wrong to allow Enron investors to sue as a group and contended that they could not be sued because they did not participate directly in the accounting fraud that led to Enron’s bankruptcy. The investors argued the court could address only whether the plaintiffs could sue as a group. Trial is set for April in Houston.

headline.main: Banks Seek to Stop Enron Class-Action Suit

abstract: The Nasdaq Stock Market has won regulatory approval to increase fees and offer more services to the 3,200 companies listed on it. The higher fees were effective Jan. 1, Nasdaq said Monday. The decision by the Securities and Exchange Commission also allows Nasdaq, an all-electronic exchange, to provide news-release distribution and Internet broadcasts at no additional charge. Nasdaq’s chief executive, Robert Greifeld, has tried to lure companies from the New York Stock Exchange through a series of acquisitions that helped Nasdaq expand beyond the business of matching buyers and sellers of shares.

Nasdaq’s chief executive, Robert Greifeld, has tried to lure companies from the New York Stock Exchange through a series of acquisitions that helped Nasdaq expand beyond the business of matching buyers and sellers of shares.

headline.main: Nasdaq to Increase Fees to Listed Companies and Add Services

abstract: Simon Property Group, the nation’s largest mall operator, had always seemed like a logical buyer for its troubled rival, the Mills Corporation. But the announcement yesterday that Simon had teamed with Farallon Capital Management, a hedge fund that owns 10.9 percent of Mills’s shares, to challenge a rival suitor and make an all-cash bid for Mills of $24 a share surprised the real estate industry because of its timing.

But the announcement yesterday that Simon had teamed with Farallon Capital Management, a hedge fund that owns 10.9 percent of Mills’s shares, to challenge a rival suitor and make an all-cash bid for Mills of $24 a share surprised the real estate industry because of its timing.

headline.main: With Mills Bid Simon Property Revisits a Deal It Abandoned

abstract: Fidelity Investments will pay $3.75 million in fines for supervisory failures, including allowing traders to accept gifts like Super Bowl tickets and chartered flights, NASD, the brokerage industry’s main regulator, said Monday. Fidelity, the world’s biggest mutual fund company, did not assign supervisors to 1,000 registered employees and let at least nine people at one subsidiary take the gifts, NASD said.

headline.main: Fidelity to Pay Fine for Failure to Supervise Gifts to Traders

abstract: Two years ago, Credit Suisse was trying to sell its bankers on yet another turnaround plan at the securities firm and looking for ways to keep frustrated investment bankers and traders from walking out the door. So Monday’s announcement of a high-level hire at Credit Suisse’s investment banking group — recruited from no less than Goldman Sachs, which is coming off a year of record profits, could be seen as a highly symbolic achievement for the firm.

headline.main: Credit Suisse Brings in Banker From Goldman

abstract: The asset manager Janus Capital Group said Monday that its chief financial officer, Dave R. Martin, and general counsel, John H. Bluher, were leaving the firm in unrelated departures. Three months ago, the chief executive, Gary D. Black, stepped down as chief investment officer in favor of two co-chief investment officers to focus on growing the business.

Three months ago, the chief executive, Gary D. Black, stepped down as chief investment officer in favor of two co-chief investment officers to focus on growing the business.

headline.main: Two Executives to Leave Janus Capital

abstract: The Federal Trade Commission made final its ruling that the memory chip designer Rambus violated antitrust laws, imposing limits on the royalties the company can charge. Wall Street was bracing for a potentially harsher order than the one the commission released Monday, and Rambus stock rose sharply.

Wall Street was bracing for a potentially harsher order than the one the commission released Monday, and Rambus stock rose sharply.

headline.main: F.T.C. Reaffirms Rambus Antitrust Ruling

abstract: Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, UBS and Deutsche Bank are among major Wall Street banks that were sent letters last month by the Securities and Exchange Commission as part of a broad examination into whether bank employees are leaking information about big trades to favored clients, The New York Times reported.
lead_paragraph: Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, UBS and Deutsche Bank are among major Wall Street banks that were sent letters last month by the Securities and Exchange Commission as part of a broad examination into whether bank employees are leaking information about big trades to favored clients, The New York Times reported.

headline.main: S.E.C. Examines Improper Stock Tipping at Major Banks

abstract: A federal judge on Monday resentenced the former chief executive of Westar Energy, David C. Wittig, to 24 months in prison for bank fraud, cutting his original sentence by more than half. But the judge, Julie A. Robinson, of United States District Court, still surpassed the six-month prison term recommended by an appellate court, saying it “failed to reflect the seriousness of the offense.”

Robinson, of United States District Court, still surpassed the six-month prison term recommended by an appellate court, saying it “failed to reflect the seriousness of the offense.”

headline.main: Former Westar Chief Given Two-Year Sentence for Bank Fraud

abstract: International Business Machines, whose stock rose 18 percent last year as it expanded in software, said on Monday that its chief executive, Samuel J. Palmisano, would be paid a $1.8 million salary in 2007 and stands to receive $5 million in incentive pay, the same as last year. Mr. Palmisano also received restricted stock units worth $3 million, vesting in 2011, and performance share units worth $7 million, payable in 2010, according to a spokesman, John Bukovinsky, and a regulatory filing.

Mr. Palmisano also received restricted stock units worth $3 million, vesting in 2011, and performance share units worth $7 million, payable in 2010, according to a spokesman, John Bukovinsky, and a regulatory filing.

headline.main: I.B.M. Details Its Chief Executive’s Pay

abstract: LinkedIn, a Web site that allows users to create online networks of business contacts, announced Monday that it had hired a new chief executive to succeed Reid Hoffman, one of Silicon Valley’s most active angel investors. While Mr. Hoffman will remain the start-up’s chairman, the move to hire Dan Nye, the former executive vice president of publicly traded Advent Software, could fuel speculation about a potential initial public offering, possibly as early as this year.

abstract: Deutsche Borse, the operator of the Frankfurt stock exchange and one-time bidder for Euronext, said Monday that it had launched a new index to track the share performance of luxury goods makers. Dubbed the World Luxury Index and made up of 20 companies, it was put together by Deutsche Borse for the Paris-based bank and investment group BNP Paribas and started on Feb. 2.

abstract: Gap management may want to take a page out of J.Crew‘s playbook and try to sell itself to a private equity firm, suggests BusinessWeek. The magazine looks at how the Texas Pacific Group‘s buyout of J. Crew transformed the retailer from an also-ran to a trend-setting retailer. Echoing a sentiment increasingly expressed by chief executives and start-up founders, BusinessWeek puts the bottom line at this: with no public shareholders to answer to, J.Crew had the time to grow.

abstract: Berkshire Partners said Monday it had acquired a majority stake in the medical-equipment businesses Masterplan and ReMedPar from Three Cities Research and Camden Partners Holdings for undisclosed terms. Berkshire, which is based in Boston, typically invests $50 million to $350 million in transactions valued at $250 million or more, according to The Deal.com.

abstract: The most eagerly anticipated auction in the German banking sector in recent years kicked off Monday with several public and private banks declaring their interest in buying Landesbank Berlin. The sale is expected to be a hotly contested affair and the outcome will be closely watched by bank executives around the world because it presents the first real opportunity for private banks to enter the previously protected savings banks sector.

The sale is expected to be a hotly contested affair and the outcome will be closely watched by bank executives around the world because it presents the first real opportunity for private banks to enter the previously protected savings banks sector.

headline.main: German Bank Auction Piques Interest

abstract: The Texas Pacific Group, Bain Capital and Goldman Sachs Funds have placed an order for a whopper of a profit. The private equity firms said Monday that they planned to sell at least 20 million of their shares in Burger King, which at Monday’s market price would raise about $400 million before fees and commissions, or up to $460 million if the underwriters over-allotment is exercised for another 3 million shares, The Deal.com calculated. They now stand to make more than four times their money on their 2002 investment.

headline.main: Burger King’s Backers Fire Up Stock Offering

abstract: Chevron announced Monday that it would separate the positions of chief executive and chairman and make it easier for shareholders to remove directors. The company, based in San Ramon, Calif., said in a public filing that the chairman will now be elected annually by the board. Previously, the oil producer’s chief executive automatically occupied the role of chairman.

headline.main: Chevron Will Split Chief and Chairman Jobs

abstract: SAC Capital, the giant hedge fund run by Steven Cohen, has recently invested in some of the same companies as the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, a coincidence that The New York Post said links investors with very different styles.

abstract: MGIC Investment, a Milwaukee-based private mortgage insurer, agreed to buy Radian Group for $4.9 billion in stock. MGIC will exchange 0.9658 share of its stock for each share of Radian, the two companies said Tuesday in a statement. That values Philadelphia-based Radian at $60.78 a share, less than its closing value of $60.84 on the New York Stock Exchange Monday.

abstract: This week’s deal to take Triad Hospitals private for $4.7 billion has rekindled speculation about which hospital chains might become targets for buyout firms. Such talk began in earnest last year when HCA agreed to be acquired by a private equity consortium in a $33 billion deal, a transaction that briefly claimed the title of the largest leveraged buyout ever.

abstract: The five biggest stocks in America are lagging this year.
snippet: The five biggest stocks in America are lagging this year.
lead_paragraph: The stock market is up so far in 2007, but Howard Silverblatt, Standard & Poor’s senior equity analyst, points out that the move has come without any help from the five largest compamies in the S.&P. 500, which between then make up 12 percent of the index.

headline.main: Too Big to Rise?

abstract: As moguls and financiers gathered last month in the snowy slopes of Davos, Switzerland, for the World Economic Forum, they were predicting a flurry of media and entertainment deals. That was one of the findings from a session called “The M&A Landscape: Developing the 2007 Heatmap,” in which a global collection of bankers, private equity executives and government officials were asked to forecast which industries would see the most deals in each of three regions: the Americas; Europe, the Middle East and Africa; and the Asia Pacific.

abstract: Forget the reports of rising salaries for law-firm associates. The story that seems to be gripping the corporate law world these days is the escalating battle between white-shoe firm Sullivan & Cromwell and a former associate who claims he was harassed because he is gay. Aaron B. Charney, who until recently worked in the firm’s mergers and acquisitions practice (ranked No. 2 for merger-advisory work last year), sued the firm last month, accusing several partners of discriminating against him and then papering over his complaints.

abstract: With billionaires, hedge funds and private equity firms sifting through the auto-parts industry for bargains, it may not be long until another parts maker attracts a takeover offer. After Lear announced Monday that Carl C. Icahn’s firm offered to buy it for about $2.4 billion, a Citigroup analyst, John Rogers, offered his list of other suppliers of automotive components that could receive buyout interest. Topping his list were Harman International Industries, with a market capitalization of about $6.4 billion, and Magna International, with a market cap of about $8.7 billion.

headline.main: Who’s Next: Auto-Parts Suppliers

abstract: Hedge funds love bold bets, and Fortress Investment Group is no exception. The fund is about to try something no other United States-based hedge fund has done before: an initial public offering. With the I.P.O. expected to price Thursday, Absolute Return writer Michelle Celarier is calling the deal “brazen,” and not just because of the valuation it puts on the firm. Writing in the magazine’s February issue, she also notes the I.P.O.’s unusual structure, in which she says Fortress’s “top guys” are “offloading risk and maintaining voting control through a complicated structure: two classes of shares for a multitiered entity topped by a new holding company in which they have no economic interest.”

abstract: Thomas Weisel Partners, the technology-oriented investment bank that went public a year ago, said that its chief financial officer, Robert K. West, would leave the firm April 6 to “pursue other interests.” Announcing the move in a regulatory filing Tuesday, the firm did not say when or how it planned to fill the vacancy. Mr. West is just the latest finance chief at a financial firm to try something new. In the past two months or so, Bank of America, Citigroup and Charles Schwab each announced that their finance chief would be leaving the post.

abstract: The Publicis Groupe, the advertising company, said fourth-quarter revenue rose 4.8 percent helped by growth in Europe and gains in North America. Revenue increased to 1.25 billion euros ($1.62 billion), Publicis said. Publicis had $500 million of net new business in the fourth quarter as it won business from Renault, Walt Disney and the Marriott Group, among others. Revenue in Europe was 530 million euros in the fourth quarter, a gain of 5.5 percent, excluding acquisitions and currency swings.

abstract: The manufacturing conglomerate Tyco International, which is preparing to split into three separate companies, said Tuesday that its profit climbed 43 percent in its most recent quarter. abstract: The former Massachusetts attorney general, Thomas F. Reilly, who left the post after an unsuccessful bid last year for the Democratic nomination for governor, will join the Boston office of the law firm Greenberg Traurig.As a partner at the firm, Mr. Reilly will draw on his breadth of experience as the state’s former top prosecutor to work on a wide range of client matters, including litigation and healthcare, environmental, and insurance issues, according to the firm. abstract: Endesa, the Spanish utility, said Tuesday that it viewed the 41 billion euro takeover bid from E.ON of Germany favorably, and its board recommended that shareholders accept the offer. “The board of Endesa has unanimously agreed that the terms of the offer are favorable,” Endesa said, adding that the offer of 38.75 euros a share from E.ON, which valued the deal at $53 billion, was “adequate from a financial standpoint.”

abstract: World Bank investigators blacklisted more than 100 firms and individuals for fraud and corruption in projects financed by the development agency over the past two years, a new report said Tuesday. abstract: Navistar International said Tuesday that the New York Stock Exchange has informed company officials that the N.Y.S.E. plans to proceed with its previously announced plan to delist Navistar from the exchange. Navistar, whose Big Board trading will be suspended at the end of trading on Feb. 13, said it intends to appeal the N.Y.S.E.’s decision. The N.Y.S.E. is moving to delist Navistar, a maker of trucks and diesel engines, because the company is so late in filing its financial results.
