abstract: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the biggest futures market in the nation, can move forward with plans to offer the first exchange-traded credit derivative contracts, after the Commodity Futures Trading Commission gave approval. Regulators will allow the exchange to trade so-called credit event futures contracts that are modeled after credit-default swaps, the privately negotiated contracts that have surged to $26 trillion in global value since they were created about a decade ago, according to a statement on the commission’s Web site.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the biggest futures market in the nation, can move forward with plans to offer the first exchange-traded credit derivative contracts, after the Commodity Futures Trading Commission gave approval. Regulators will allow the exchange to trade so-called credit event futures contracts that are modeled after credit-default swaps, the privately negotiated contracts that have surged to $26 trillion in global value since they were created about a decade ago, according to a statement on the commission’s Web site.

headline.main: Chicago Merc Gets Green Light for Credit-Derivatives Trading

abstract: A travel search company, SideStep, has raised $15 million in a Series C round of funding led by Norwest Venture Partners, CNet News.com reported. The investment, which CNet said SideStep plans to announce on Wednesday, is the largest single injection yet for the company, bringing its total venture capital to $32 million. Other investors reportedly include Trident Capital, Leader Ventures and Saints Capital. The report said that the company, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., plans to use the cash to pay for acquisitions in the United States, Europe and Asia.

The report said that the company, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., plans to use the cash to pay for acquisitions in the United States, Europe and Asia.

abstract: Directors of The Mills Corporation, a mall developer, told company leaders Tuesday to start discussions with the Simon Property Group and Farallon Capital Management over their offer to buy the company. Responding to the pair’s offer, which would top a $1.35 billion deal with a Canadian investor, Brookfield Asset Management, the Mills board determined that the competing $1.6 billion bid “is reasonably likely to lead to a superior competing transaction,” company officials said in a statement.

abstract: Shares in Novelis, a former division of Alcan, rose almost 11 percent to a record high on Tuesday following reports that it will receive a takeover offer in the coming weeks. And on Tuesday, Bloomberg News reported that Hindalco Industries, part of the Aditya Birla Group of India, may make a takeover bid this week valued at $6 billion to $8 billion, citing the Indian financial Web site, MoneyControl.com.

abstract: For the second time in less than three years, companies tied to a Houston oil-field-services firm, Vetco Gray, are paying millions to settle charges of illegally bribing Nigerian officials. abstract: RBC Capital Markets, the investment banking arm of the Royal Bank of Canada, said Wednesday that it had named two co-presidents as part of its “long-term succession planning.” The co-presidents, Doug McGregor and Mark Standish, will report to Chuck Winograd, chief executive of RBC Capital Markets. Mr. McGregor, based in Toronto, had been head of global investment banking and equity markets for RBC Capital, while Mr. Standish, based in New York, had been head of global markets.
lead_paragraph: RBC Capital Markets, the investment banking arm of the Royal Bank of Canada, said Wednesday that it had named two co-presidents as part of its “long-term succession planning.” The co-presidents, Doug McGregor and Mark Standish, will report to Chuck Winograd, chief executive of RBC Capital Markets. Mr. McGregor, based in Toronto, had been head of global investment banking and equity markets for RBC Capital, while Mr. Standish, based in New York, had been head of global markets.

headline.main: RBC Capital Names Co-Presidents

abstract: Is General Electric considering a sale of NBC Universal? Amid all the hubub surrounding the appointment of Jeff Zucker as the president and chief executive of NBC Universal, a report surfaced suggesting that the increased involvement of G.E.’s chairman, Jeff Immelt, in the direction of its entertainment filial could be a sign that it is mulling an eventual exit from the TV and film business.
lead_paragraph: Is General Electric considering a sale of NBC Universal? Amid all the hubub surrounding the appointment of Jeff Zucker as the president and chief executive of NBC Universal, a report surfaced suggesting that the increased involvement of G.E.’s chairman, Jeff Immelt, in the direction of its entertainment filial could be a sign that it is mulling an eventual exit from the TV and film business.

headline.main: Zucker’s Bumpy Ride to the Top

abstract: In a three-way Midwestern energy deal, Great Plains Energy will buy Aquila for $1.7 billion in cash and stock, after Aquila sells assets in four states to Black Hills for $940 million. Great Plains, the parent of Kansas City Power & Light, will pay $4.54 a share, a 2.8 percent discount to Aquila’s closing price on Tuesday of $4.67. Each acquisition is dependent on the other.
lead_paragraph: In a three-way Midwestern energy deal, Great Plains Energy will buy Aquila for $1.7 billion in cash and stock, after Aquila sells assets in four states to Black Hills for $940 million. Great Plains, the parent of Kansas City Power & Light, will pay $4.54 a share, a 2.8 percent discount to Aquila’s closing price on Tuesday of $4.67. Each acquisition is dependent on the other.

headline.main: Midwestern Utilities Strike a 3-Way Deal

abstract: The Blackstone Group emerged Wednesday as the winner in the feverish battle to acquire Equity Office Properties Trust after shareholders overwhelmingly approved the buyout firm’s offer. The $39 billion deal now stands as the largest buyout ever.

abstract: Michael M. Thomas, the investment banker turned financial fiction writer, uses his New York Observer column this week to describe a disturbing (and, we hope, fictional) potential plot. abstract: New York Times columnist Ben Stein and the legions of other critics of management-led buyouts have it all wrong, according to TheEconomist.com. abstract: Here is one way that Richard Fuld, chief executive of Lehman Brothers, can spend some of the $186 million in stock grants he is expected to get over the next 10 years: sprucing up what The New York Post describes as his new “16-room fixer-upper” on Park Avenue, for which he reportedly paid $21 million. The apartment had been owned by Evelyn Annenberg Jaffe Hall, the publishing heiress who died in 2005 at age 93. The four-bedroom, 5-1/2 bath apartment has “great bones” but “needs a ton of work” a broker told the Post. Renovations will cost another $10 million, the broker estimated.
lead_paragraph: Here is one way that Richard Fuld, chief executive of Lehman Brothers, can spend some of the $186 million in stock grants he is expected to get over the next 10 years: sprucing up what The New York Post describes as his new “16-room fixer-upper” on Park Avenue, for which he reportedly paid $21 million. The apartment had been owned by Evelyn Annenberg Jaffe Hall, the publishing heiress who died in 2005 at age 93. The four-bedroom, 5-1/2 bath apartment has “great bones” but “needs a ton of work” a broker told the Post. Renovations will cost another $10 million, the broker estimated.

headline.main: Lehman Chief’s Next Hire: a Good Contractor?

abstract: Siemens, the German engineering company, banned its sales managers from using consultants for winning new orders after an investigation into whether money was embezzled through such agreements to bribe customers. “We decided to introduce a general ban on the use of consultant agreements in our sales organization,” a spokeswoman, Monika Bruecklmeier, said. Exceptions can be granted only through the company’s head of compliance, she said. An investigation of such payments has spread to at least six countries and forced the company to review 420 million euros ($544 million) in payments, and has put pressure on Siemens to explain how the suspected system of bribes went unchecked by top management.

abstract: Production at Mexico’s giant Cantarell oil field will fall by 15 percent this year, Jesús Reyes Heróles, left, the director general of Petróleos Mexicanos, Mexico’s state-owned oil monopoly, said. Output dropped 13.1 percent last year. Mr. Reyes Heróles, a former energy minister who took over at Pemex in December, said other projects would help make up for the shortfall at Cantarell, which last year accounted for about 55 percent of Pemex’s overall production of 3.26 million barrels a day. Mexico is a top supplier of imported oil to the United States. Mr. Reyes Heróles said that the company needed additional investment of $8 billion to $10 billion a year to keep up production, develop new reserves, expand its refining capacity and modernize its storage and transport network. But Pemex is closed to private investment and cannot finance the investment itself. Last year, Pemex sales surpassed $100 billion but it paid $79 billion in taxes, which accounted for almost 40 percent of Mexico’s federal budget.

Mexico is a top supplier of imported oil to the United States. Mr. Reyes Heróles said that the company needed additional investment of $8 billion to $10 billion a year to keep up production, develop new reserves, expand its refining capacity and modernize its storage and transport network. But Pemex is closed to private investment and cannot finance the investment itself. Last year, Pemex sales surpassed $100 billion but it paid $79 billion in taxes, which accounted for almost 40 percent of Mexico’s federal budget.

The purchase will probably be completed by April, according to the Imperial Tobacco.

abstract: The British bank HSBC Holdings said on Wednesday that its charge for bad debts would be more than $10.5 billion for 2006, some 20 percent above analysts’ average forecasts, because of problems in its mortgage portfolio. HSBC said in a trading update late on Wednesday that slowing growth in house prices was being reflected in accelerated delinquency trends across the subprime mortgage market, particularly in more recent loans.

EMC, which specializes in data storage, bought VMware for $635 million three years ago. Industry analysts said the public offering could well value the company at more than 10 times that.

abstract: Charles W. Goodyear, the affable Texan and chief executive who adroitly steered BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, through China’s bull market for resources, told shareholders on Wednesday that he would leave in December, and he delivered an early farewell gift: record half-year earnings and a $10 billion stock buyback.

abstract: An Egyptian billionaire, Naguib Sawiris, agreed Wednesday to buy TIM Hellas Telecommunications from two buyout firms in a deal that valued the Greek cellphone company at about 3.4 billion euros and extended his reach in Europe. The deal provides an exit for sellers Apax Partners Worldwide and the Texas Pacific Group, which bought TIM Hellas two years ago for 1.4 billion euros. Mr. Sawiris, through his holding company, Weather Investments, will pay 500 million euros, or $650 million, and take on 2.9 billion euros in debt.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian billionaire, Naguib Sawiris, agreed Wednesday to buy TIM Hellas Telecommunications from two buyout firms in a deal that valued the Greek cellphone company at about 3.4 billion euros and extended his reach in Europe. The deal provides an exit for sellers Apax Partners Worldwide and the Texas Pacific Group, which bought TIM Hellas two years ago for 1.4 billion euros. Mr. Sawiris, through his holding company, Weather Investments, will pay 500 million euros, or $650 million, and take on 2.9 billion euros in debt.

headline.main: Egyptian Billionaire Takes Control of Greece’s TIM Hellas

abstract: The New York Stock Exchange Wednesday said it had fined Morgan Stanley $300,000 for its failure to stop a trader from entering an order to buy $10.8 billion of stocks – not $10.8 million as intended – an error that disrupted trading in nearly 700 listed stocks. The N.Y.S.E. said Morgan Stanley did not have appropriate blocks within its trading systems to prevent an erroneous order from being routed to the N.Y.S.E. floor and failed to properly supervise and train traders.
lead_paragraph: The New York Stock Exchange Wednesday said it had fined Morgan Stanley $300,000 for its failure to stop a trader from entering an order to buy $10.8 billion of stocks – not $10.8 million as intended – an error that disrupted trading in nearly 700 listed stocks. The N.Y.S.E. said Morgan Stanley did not have appropriate blocks within its trading systems to prevent an erroneous order from being routed to the N.Y.S.E. floor and failed to properly supervise and train traders.

headline.main: N.Y.S.E. Fines Morgan Stanley for Disruptive Trade

abstract: Edgars Consolidated Stores, South Africa’s biggest retailer by market value, agreed to be bought by Bain Capital for about 25 billion rand ($3.5 billion) in what would be the country’s largest private equity transaction. The offer is worth 46 rand a share, 15 percent above Wednesday’s closing price. Edgars, which has more than 900 stores in South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Namibia and Swaziland, said that it “recognizes that although its prospects remain positive, its future performance and corresponding growth profile are not without risk.”
lead_paragraph: Edgars Consolidated Stores, South Africa’s biggest retailer by market value, agreed to be bought by Bain Capital for about 25 billion rand ($3.5 billion) in what would be the country’s largest private equity transaction. Edgars, which has more than 900 stores in South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Namibia and Swaziland, said that it “recognizes that although its prospects remain positive, its future performance and corresponding growth profile are not without risk.”

headline.main: Bain Bags South African Retailer

abstract: While it battles CVS over Caremark Rx, Express Scripts may have some trouble in its own backyard. The prescription benefits manager has given stock option grants to its management at unusually lucrative times, The New York Post reported Thursday. The report arrives as Express Scripts criticizes Caremark executives for planning to enrich themselves through a $24.6 billion merger with CVS. Though its $26 billion bid was rejected, Express Scripts has already begun a tender offer for Caremark shares.

abstract: Goldman Sachs and Sanyo Electric are set to sell their combined 50 percent stake in the leasing firm Sanyo Electric Credit to G.E. A Sanyo Electric spokesman said no official decision has been made to sell its stake in the credit unit.

abstract: A composite radar image of corporate jets departing the Miami area on Monday morning — the day after the Super Bowl took place there — appears to show a parade of planes making beelines for New York, many of them doubtless hauling their human cargo back to jobs on Wall Street. A considerable number were headed to Chicago, and another handful seemed to be flying to, well, flyover country. The image, accessible Wednesday at the Air Transport Association’s smartskies.org, has since been removed from that site, but not before it was picked up by other sites to be made the object of snarky comments. (Update: The image is back, at least for now.)

abstract: On Thursday, Holland & Knight became the latest law firm to raise the pay of its first-year associates. In doing so, it joins a long line of firms that are increasing compensation offers as competition to attract and retain young lawyers gets hotter. Still, the National Law Journal suggests that, while increases for associates may sound impressive, as measured against what law firm’s partners are getting, associates’ pay is actually falling.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Holland & Knight became the latest law firm to raise the pay of its first-year associates. Still, the National Law Journal suggests that, while increases for associates may sound impressive, as measured against what law firm’s partners are getting, associates’ pay is actually falling.

headline.main: In the Law-Firm Pay Race, Who’s Really Ahead?

abstract: Barry Diller has for more than a decade been resolutely skeptical about the Internet, even as he has become one of the industry’s most powerful moguls. During the early part of the dot-com boom, before he became the head of a company (IAC/InterActiveCorp) that would own such Internet properties as CitySearch, Ask.com, and Ticketmaster, he often surveyed the Internet landscape — planted with capital-rich and profit-poor WebVans and Pets.coms — and professed to be mystified at how anyone could expect to make enough money from such ventures to justify their valuations.

abstract: Australia’s jobless rate fell to a 31-year low in January as fewer people sought work, worsening a worker shortage that may fuel wages and inflation. The rate fell to 4.5 percent from 4.6 percent in December, the lowest since May 1976. Australian employers hired an extra 300,000 workers last year, the largest gain since 1989..

abstract: South Korea’s central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged for a sixth month after consumer prices increased at the slowest pace in seven years. The Bank of Korea, led by its governor, Lee Seong-tae, left the overnight call rate at a five-year high of 4.5 percent. “Economic growth has weakened,” Mr. Lee, left, said. “Consumer prices have stabilized.” The bank raised rates three times in 2006. Recent reports showing that the economy grew at the slowest pace in 18 months and that household debt fell for the first time in a year ended expectations that the central bank would raise rates in the first half of this year.

abstract: Two private equity firms have gotten the cold shoulder from shareholders of Eddie Bauer. In a surprise turn, the chain of outdoorsy clothing stores said Thursday that its agreement to be bought by Sun Capital Partners and Golden Gate Capital failed to win enough votes from shareholders, meaning that the company will stay publicly traded for now. The Seattle Post-Intelligencer reported that Thursday’s special meeting to vote on the deal, held in Bellevue, Wash., drew only 22 people, including Eddie Bauer directors, executives, employees and the media. No shareholders spoke at the meeting, the Post-Intellegencer said.

No shareholders spoke at the meeting, the Post-Intellegencer said.

abstract: Alcatel-Lucent, the world’s biggest maker of telecommunications equipment, will deepen job cuts after reporting a fourth-quarter loss, increasing its savings target to 1.7 billion euros ($2.2 billion) within three years. The company plans to axe 12,500 jobs following its $11.6 billion merger last year, an increase from an original plan to shed 9,000 workers, it said in a statement Friday.

abstract: How do you become less secretive about your business without actually talking about it? Such is the conundrum faced by hedge funds, which are described more often than not as secretive. Hedge funds are governed by a Securities and Exchange Commission rule that prohibits them from engaging in anything that could be construed as advertising or any kind of general solicitation. To hedge funds’ cautious general counsels, that means no talking on the record to the news media about the fund.

Mr. Rosenthal was preceded by his son Amir and followed by his son Ayal in admitting the conspiracy.

abstract: The initial public offering of National CineMedia, which provides movie theater advertising services, jumped as much as 26 percent in its market debut on Thursday, a day after pricing above a forecasted range. National CineMedia shares rose as high as $26.50 in morning trading and was trading up nearly 20 percent on Nasdaq in midday trade. The company raised $798 million Wednesday from the sale of 38 million shares sold at $21 apiece, above the forecasted range of $18 to $20.

abstract: Eddie Bauer‘s proposed buyout collapsed this week, and last year’s auction of Jones Apparel Group ended with no sale. Even so, analysts at Citigroup say that cash-rish private equity firms could still find many tempting takeover targets in the retail industry. Liz Claiborne was one company they said had the kind of strong cash flows and low debt levels that often get private equity firms’ attention. One of the least attractive targets, the analysts said, is Gap, whose weak sales and management turmoil have made it the subject of buyout speculation.

abstract: The Super Bowl ads for Snickers were criticized for being homophobic and were quickly pulled. However, Snickers.com’s share of all Web visits was almost 16 times larger than it had been a week earlier.

lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl ads for Snickers were criticized for being homophobic and were quickly pulled. But they worked in one respect: Snickers.com’s share of all Web visits was almost 16 times larger than it had been a week earlier, according to the traffic-measurement firm Hitwise. Budlight.com saw its share grow by 655.87 percent. (Hitwise reports Web site traffic as a proportion of all Internet activity, rather than an absolute number of visits.)

abstract: Gary B. Pruitt, the head of McClatchy, seems to have lost his long-held place as the darling of the industry and of Wall Street. Last week, its stock price hit a 52-week low, $37.82.

abstract: Finance ministers from the world’s leading economies put the $1.4 trillion hedge fund industry on the international policy agenda on Saturday, saying they would scrutinize the sector with an eye toward encouraging more self-regulation. Representatives from the Group of 7 nations, who met in the industrial center of the host country, Germany, issued a statement saying that the practices of hedge funds, which have drawn growing concern from financial policy makers over the last few years, have “become more complex and challenging” in light of the industry’s prominence and volatility.

abstract: Investors stormed the Fortress Investment Group Friday, driving its shares up 67.6 percent in the first American market offering of a hedge fund manager. The offering was eagerly anticipated because it gives a much bigger pool of investors the opportunity to share in the returns of hedge funds and private equity. Those alternative private investments are limited to the very wealthy and to large institutional investors like pension funds and university endowments.

abstract: Lehman Brothers‘ top-producing banker, George H. Young III, resigned abruptly late Friday, raising questions about the investment bank on Wall Street. The reason for the departure was unclear, although people close to Mr. Young said it was the result of a long dispute with senior management over the strategic direction of the firm, The New York Times reported. Separately, there were reports Monday that Bob Maguire, co-head of Morgan Stanley‘s energy investment banking team, plans to leave the investment bank after more than 20 years there. And Financial News said that George Boutros, a top technology banker at Credit Suisse, has signed a contract that will keep him at the firm for another year.

abstract: After recruiting a collection of well-known dealmakers, fledgling investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners is putting them to work. (A few of them, anyway.) The firm has been hired by Lamson & Sessions, which makes pipes, wiring-outlet cases and other plastic fittings, to explore strategic options including a sale or all or part of the company, Lamson said in a press release Monday. Ramius Capital Group, a major shareholder in the company, has been pressuring it to sell its polyvinyl chloride pipes unit. Shares of Lamson & Sessions rose 6 percent to $28.44 Monday, giving the company a market capitalization of about $450 million.

abstract: Coincidence? We think not. Only a few weeks after billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn took a 14.6 percent stake in WCI Communities and said he planned to have a talk with the homebuilder’s management about ways to “unlock the inherent value of the shares,” WCI announced that it hired Goldman Sachs to review its business plans “with the objective of enhancing the company’s value for all of its shareholders.” Among the actions being considered are share buybacks or a sale of the company, WCI chief executive Jerry Starkey said in a press release Monday (which made no mention of Mr. Icahn).

abstract: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 12 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ — Johnson & Johnson today voluntarily disclosed to the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that subsidiaries outside the United States are believed to have made improper payments in connection with the sale of medical devices in two small-market countries. The actions were contrary to the Company's policies, and the payments may fall within the jurisdiction of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The Company will provide additional information to DOJ and SEC, and will cooperate with the agencies' reviews of these matters.
lead_paragraph: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 12 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ — Johnson & Johnson today voluntarily disclosed to the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that subsidiaries outside the United States are believed to have made improper payments in connection with the sale of medical devices in two small-market countries. The actions were contrary to the Company's policies, and the payments may fall within the jurisdiction of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The Company will provide additional information to DOJ and SEC, and will cooperate with the agencies' reviews of these matters.

abstract: Shares of Bristol-Myers Squibb declined as much as 4 percent Monday after the Times of London reported over the weekend that its talks to merge with Sanofi Aventis, a deal that would form the world’s No. 2 drugmaker, had been called off. The newspaper said the discussions — reported late last month but never acknowledged by either side — faltered because of disagreements about price and the legal uncertainty surrounding Bristol Myers’ top-selling drug, Plavix. A UBS analyst called the report “surprising” and said in a research note that Bristol-Myers was probably still in play.

abstract: The Polish government is preparing a plan to privatize the Warsaw Stock Exchange by selling shares exclusively to Polish companies, possibly in defiance of European Union rules that require equal treatment for all members of the bloc. In a little-noticed speech filled with patriotic themes, the treasury minister, Wojciech Jasinski, outlined a strategy last month to sell 49 percent of the government’s holdings to “Polish investors” in blocks of 5 percent to 10 percent. The government also intends to introduce rules to prevent companies listed on the exchange from being taken over by foreign companies to ensure that the exchange retains its Polish character, Mr. Jasinski said. The plan appears ripe for a conflict with European Union rules, which require privatizations to be open to all union members. Catherine Bunyan, a spokeswoman for Charlie McCreevy, the union commissioner for the internal market, said Brussels was not aware of Warsaw’s plans.

abstract: LATE TO THE GATE Airlines last year had the lowest percentage of on-time arrivals since 2000, according to the Bureau of Transportation Statistics in the Transportation Department. In 2006, domestic aircraft arrived on schedule 75.45 percent of the time, compared with 72.59 percent in 2000. The five airlines with the worst on-time arrival rates last year were Skywest (63.9 percent); American Eagle, owned by AMR (64.3 percent); JetBlue Airways (64.8 percent); Alaska Air (66.3 percent); and Northwest Airlines (66.6 percent). As for luggage, with a sharp increase in the number of checked bags because tighter security procedures reduced the number of carry-on bags, airlines mishandled bags at a rate of 6.73 per 1,000 passengers, a slight increase over 2005 (6.64 per 1,000 passengers).

abstract: SXR Uranium One agreed to buy UrAsia Energy for $3.1 billion to form the world’s second-largest uranium producer as rising demand for nuclear fuel drives prices to records. SXR, owner of South Africa’s largest undeveloped uranium deposit, bid 7.05 Canadian dollars ($6.01) a share for UrAsia, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, and owns mines in Central Asia. That was 13 percent more than UrAsia’s Feb. 9 closing price in Toronto, the companies said. SXR’s stock rose 6.8 percent to a record. The combined company, once all its mines are operating, will trail only Cameco in production and be the only producer in Kazakhstan, South Africa, Australia, the United States and Canada, the five largest holders of uranium deposits.

abstract: UBS, the securities company, said Tuesday that its fourth-quarter net income fell 47 percent from a year ago, when asset sales helped increase profits. Profit from continuing operations rose 19 percent, however. UBS also raised its dividend and announced a three-year stock repurchase program valued at as much as 16 billion Swiss francs ($12.8 billion).

Profit from continuing operations rose 19 percent, however. abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun to take steps on two fronts to protect corporations, executives and accounting firms from investor lawsuits that accuse them of fraud. abstract: MTV Networks plans to dismiss 250 people, or 5.5 percent of its staff of 4,500, the network’s chief executive, Judy McGrath, told employees in an e-mail message Monday. Although Ms. McGrath did not say how much was hoped to be saved from the move, her message said that the money would be used to invest “in our television and digital future, and to keep winning in this revolutionary environment.” Viacom, MTV’s parent company, is rushing to develop new interactive businesses.

abstract: Caremark Rx, facing mounting opposition to its proposed $23.7 billion acquisition by pharmacy chain CVS, said Tuesday it would triple the special dividend payable to its shareholders after the deal closes. abstract: Henry Blodget is apparently getting a lot of mileage out of his war of the words with colorful stock-picker Jim Cramer. Jim Cramer, Round 2, Mr. Blodget meticulously answers critics of his first column, in which he pilloried Mr. Cramer for leading mom-and-pop investors to believe that they could beat the pros.

abstract: Citigroup is folding up its umbrella and giving “group” the boot. The financial-services giant said Tuesday that it was rebranding itself under the name “Citi” and would sell the trademark for its signature red umbrella, which it acquired through its landmark merger with the insurance company Travelers Group. The announcement confirmed last month’s report by Eric Dash of The New York Times, who said the rebranding is part of an “ambitious campaign by [Citigroup’s] chairman and chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, to better integrate the bank’s sprawling parts after years of acquisitions.”

Further cooling the takeover chatter, Susan Lyne, the company’s chief executive, recently told TheStreet.com that a buyout is “unlikely.”

abstract: Goldman Sachs apparently tipped its hand on the base pay level for its elite crew of partner managing directors. Not surprisingly, it’s a lot. Citing a recent regulatory filing, Financial News reported that the base pay for partner managing directors at Goldman is $600,000 a year, which it said is about three times what regular managing directors make at Goldman and other comparable banks. Of course, the salary is loose change compared with the year-end bonuses awarded to employees with this lofty title, which is a relic carried over from Goldman’s days as a private partnership.

abstract: In the fierce contest to acquire Caremark Rx, a judge has called time out. Granting a request from a Louisiana pension fund that owns shares of the company, a judge in Delaware’s Court of Chancery said Tuesday he would block a shareholder vote on Caremark’s proposed merger with drugstore chain CVS, which had been scheduled for Feb. 20. “The court is not confident that all Caremark shareholders would be able to make an informed decision if they are required to vote on February 20,” Judge William B. Chandler III said in a letter, Reuters reported.

abstract: Five companies were picked by the government as finalists in the bidding for its stake in Alitalia, the ailing state-controlled carrier. The bidders include the Texas Pacific Group, the private equity firm; UniCredit, the bank; as well as financier Carlo De Benedetti’s Management and Capitali, MatlinPatterson Global Advisers; and Carlo Toto, owner of Italy’s No. 2 carrier, Air One, the finance ministry said. They have until mid-April to submit preliminary offers. Italy decided in December to sell its stake in the country’s largest airline after the government abandoned turnaround efforts. Alitalia last reported a profit in 2002 and has forecast a loss in 2006.

abstract: Nasdaq Stock Market Chief Executive Robert Greifeld had what seemed like a somewhat novel take on his resounding defeat on the bid for the London Stock Exchange. Speaking Tuesday during a conference call to announce Nasdaq’s fourth-quarter results, Mr. Greifeld said that he “chose not to win” the war for the overseas rival, after L.S.E. shareholders, calling Nasdaq’s bid of 2.7 billion pounds ($5.3 billion) too low, suggested higher prices they might accept. Nasdaq ended up with commitments of less than 0.5 percent from L.S.E. shareholders.

abstract: Why stop at $39 billion? And in this private equity boom, giants once thought of as unthinkable buyout candidates — Home Depot, Yahoo — have been floated as possible targets.

abstract: Societe Generale, France’s third-largest bank, reported a 6.3 percent gain in fourth-quarter profit on higher consumer lending outside its home market and increased revenue at the investment bank. Net income climbed to 1.18 billion euros ($1.54 billion), or 2.71 euros a share, from 1.11 billion euros, or 2.69 euros a share, a year earlier. Profit missed the 1.24 billion euro median estimate of 12 analysts Bloomberg News surveyed by phone and e-mail. Costs and bad-loan provisions exceeded forecasts.

headline.main: Societe Generale Reports Profit Increase

abstract: Shares of DaimlerChrysler rose 4 percent Wednesday after the company suggested that a sale of its Chrysler unit, which lost nearly $1.5 billion last year, was not out of the question. The idea has been raised a number of times by DaimlerChrysler shareholders and industry analysts, and DaimlerChrysler has previously said that a spinoff of the unit was possible. But Wednesday’s declaration that “no option is being excluded in the interest of arriving at the best possible solution for the Chrysler Group and DaimlerChrysler as a whole,” accompanied by a plan to eliminate 13,000 Chrysler jobs, seemed to increase speculation that DaimlerChrysler was preparing to seek out potential buyers for the unit.

abstract: Gradient Analytics can breathe a little easier now. abstract: He may have been autocratic and very well compensated, but former Home Depot chief executive Robert Nardelli may also have been onto something. That is the suggestion that a few analysts are making as they evaluate the recent decision by Mr. Nardelli’s successor, Frank Blake, to consider selling Home Depot’s contractor-supply business. Building that business was a pet project of Mr. Nardelli, who was convinced that the consumer remodeling market was reaching maturity. He pinned his strategy — and much of the company’s capital — on HD Supply, the Home Depot division that serves commercial customers.

abstract: Nearly five years after Wall Street’s sweeping settlement with regulators over its conflicted research business, “the analytical path of least resistance still reigns,” writes BusinessWeek’s Roben Farzad. That sounds a little like the dilemma faced by the Washington press corps, often accused with avoiding tough questions to keep lines of communication open. But Richard S. Greenfield of Pali Research may be the Helen Thomas of Wall Street analysts. He “stands out in the sea of noncommittal analysis by making pointed demands, the sort you hear from an agitating hedge fund manager, Mr. Farzad writes.

abstract: If the single-payer system embraced by virtually all other developed countries is clearly the best solution, why doesn’t the United States adopt it?

lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union address, President Bush proposed tax cuts to make health insurance more affordable for the uninsured. The next day, Stephen Colbert had this to say on his show on Comedy Central: “It’s so simple. Most people who can’t afford health insurance also are too poor to owe taxes. But if you give them a deduction from the taxes they don’t owe, they can use the money they’re not getting back from what they haven’t given to buy the health care they can’t afford.”

abstract: Corporate profits in Germany have surged across sectors ranging from finance to autos to energy, as German executives have turned the country into one of the world’s largest exporters over the last five years. These days, Mr. Schaupensteiner’s backlog of bribery, fraud and other white-collar crime cases runs into the hundreds.

abstract: Credit Suisse said Thursday that chief executive Oswald Grubel would retire in May, far earlier than many had expected, and would be succeeded by Brady Dougan, the head of its investment banking unit. The surprise move will put an American in charge of the Switzerland-based securities giant as it seeks to more closely integrate its operations under what it calls the “one bank” strategy. Mr. Dougan has been with Credit Suisse for 17 years and became chief executive of its investment banking group, formerly called Credit Suisse First Boston, when John J. Mack abruptly left the firm in 2004.

abstract: Berkshire Hathaway, the investment vehicle of famed value investor Warren E. Buffett, has revealed its end-of-2006 stock positions, including its $843 million stake in Minneapolis-based U.S. Bancorp. From January through September of last year, Berkshire built up its U.S. Bancorp holdings by 23.3 million shares, representing a 1.3 percent stake in the bank, the nation’s sixth-largest by assets. abstract: Singapore cut corporate taxes for the first time in three years to lure more international financial services and technology companies. The government will reduce the maximum tax rate payable by companies to 18 percent from 20 percent from the 2008 year of assessment, according to the second minister for finance, Tharman Shanmugaratnam, above. The tax on goods and services will be increased 2 percentage points, to 7 percent, from July 1 to make up for the revenue shortfall from lower collections from companies, he said. The government of Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong intends to attract 11.9 billion Singapore dollars ($7.7 billion) of investment in services and manufacturing industries this year to underpin growth.

abstract: L’Oréal, the world’s largest cosmetics maker, said profit rose in 2006 as the company sold more Lancôme luxury makeup and Armani Code perfume. Net income climbed to 1.83 billion euros ($2.4 billion), after adjustment for some items, from 1.64 billion euros in 2005, the company said. Revenue for the year rose 8.7 percent, to 15.8 billion euros. In the fourth quarter, it rose 10 percent, to 4.2 billion euros. Sales of luxury cosmetics rose 5.3 percent in the year, helped by Armani Code perfume, while revenue from antiwrinkle products like Normaderm Nuit from Vichy rose 14 percent. L’Oréal, which is based in Paris, said costs related to the acquisition of the Body Shop retail chain last year and an increase in expenses for research and development would hurt profit this year.

abstract: A former top executive of Monster Worldwide, the company that runs the Monster.com job search Web site, admitted in court Thursday that he illegally backdated millions of dollars in employee stock option grants. Myron F. Olesnyckyj, 45, of New Providence, N.J., pleaded to securities fraud and conspiracy to commit securities fraud, charges that carry potential penalties of up to 25 years in prison and fines of more than $5.2 million. He promised to cooperate, which can earn him leniency. Mr. Olesnyckyj, a former senior vice president for Monster, agreed to forfeit $381,000, which he said represented the amount he had illegally gained.
lead_paragraph: A former top executive of Monster Worldwide, the company that runs the Monster.com job search Web site, admitted in court Thursday that he illegally backdated millions of dollars in employee stock option grants. Myron F. Olesnyckyj, 45, of New Providence, N.J., pleaded to securities fraud and conspiracy to commit securities fraud, charges that carry potential penalties of up to 25 years in prison and fines of more than $5.2 million. He promised to cooperate, which can earn him leniency. Mr. Olesnyckyj, a former senior vice president for Monster, agreed to forfeit $381,000, which he said represented the amount he had illegally gained.

headline.main: Former Monster Executive Admits Backdating Options

abstract: The furor over a company from the United Arab Emirates operating terminals at the Port of Newark has been nearly matched this week by turmoil surrounding its exit. Over the past year, DP World, the port operator owned by the royal Maktoum family of Dubai, has been under stiff political pressure to sell its rights to run terminals in ports around the United States. So in December, DP World reached an agreement estimated at more than a billion dollars to sell its leases to A.I.G. Global Investment Group, an arm of the American insurance giant.

abstract: On Jan. 14, 2000, Martin A. abstract: />One of the things that sets Brady W. Dougan apart from his peers is his aversion to the limelight. But Mr. Dougan, who was anointed Credit Suisse Group‘s chief executive Thursday, will be the youngest chief executive of a global banking giant, a position that is by no means a private one. Mr. Dougan, whom The New York Times describes a shy, workaholic from the Midwest who ran marathons in near world-class times and acknowledges an addiction to Diet Dr Pepper, stands in contrast with many of Wall Street’s top executives, whose aggressive charm has paved their way to the top.
lead_paragraph: />One of the things that sets Brady W. Dougan apart from his peers is his aversion to the limelight. But Mr. Dougan, who was anointed Credit Suisse Group‘s chief executive Thursday, will be the youngest chief executive of a global banking giant, a position that is by no means a private one. Mr. Dougan, whom The New York Times describes a shy, workaholic from the Midwest who ran marathons in near world-class times and acknowledges an addiction to Diet Dr Pepper, stands in contrast with many of Wall Street’s top executives, whose aggressive charm has paved their way to the top.

headline.main: Credit Suisse’s New No-Frills Chief

abstract: Shares of Salzgitter, Germany’s second-largest steelmaker, fell for the first day in four after the company said that it is in talks to buy Canadian competitor Algoma Steel. Salzgitter, based in the German city of the same name, said late Thursday that it is in “very preliminary” talks with Algoma. Algoma confirmed the talks and said any offer will probably be below its current share price. Shares of Algoma rose 13 percent to a record C$50.44 yesterday, valuing the company at C$1.6 billion ($1.4 billion).

abstract: Portuguese telecommunications group Sonaecom on Thursday raised its bid for rival Portugal Telecom from 9.50 euros to 10.50 euros a share, increasing the value of its hostile takeover bid from 10.7 billion euros to almost 12 billion euros ($15.7 billion). abstract: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, Spain’s second-biggest bank, agreed to buy Compass Bancshares for $9.6 billion to gain a greater foothold in the consumer-lending market in the southern United States. The Spanish bank is offering Compass shareholders $71.82 in cash or 2.8 new BBVA shares for each Compass share. The offer represents an 8.2 percent premium to Compass’s closing price yesterday of $66.37. Speculation about an imminent bid sent Compass shares up $4.59, or 7.4 percent, Thursday.

abstract: It may be having financial troubles, but Mills Corporation apparently still knows how to play bidders against each other. abstract: In New York’s West 27th Street club scene, they’re called “bottles.” In New York magazine’s recent profile of Club Row’s rise and fall, they’re referred to as businessmen. And the blog suggests that Wall Street bankers, many of whom consider nights among models ordering overpriced bottles of premium alcohol to be part of the job description, did their part to build the neighborhood up and then ruin the vibe.

abstract: Days after Chrysler’s parent company said it would not rule out a sale of the struggling unit, there were reports Friday that General Motors was negotiating to buy it. Shares of DaimlerChrysler, which owns Chrysler, rose 3.6 percent. Citing unnamed sources, The Automotive News said that G.M. and DaimlerChrysler executives have held “high-level” discussions on a deal. But Micheline Maynard  of The New York Times reported on Friday that while investors were cheered by DaimlerChrysler’s willingness to let go of Chrysler, Wall Street analysts were skeptical that it would be bought outright by G.M.

abstract: Steel makers have been some of the hottest stocks in the market, with many of them soaring more than 50 percent over the last 12 months. That performance has largely been attributable to a series of global mergers, including the $12 billion acquisition of the Corus Group, a British-Dutch company, by Tata Steel of India. It hasn’t been based on the fundamentals of the steel market in the United States, which have been miserable, with a glut of imports driving down prices.

abstract: David F. Swensen never appears on lists of the most highly paid money managers. But in his competitive world, he can boast of an extraordinary record: In his 21 years at Yale, Mr. Swensen has generated an annual compound growth rate of 16.3 percent, besting the performance of Harvard’s endowment and that of every other major school in the country. He has routinely rebuffed lucrative offers to leave Yale and to cash in on his expertise.

abstract: Scor, France’s largest reinsurer, offered to buy Converium Holding for 3.1 billion Swiss francs ($2.5 billion) in the latest deal in the global reinsurance sector. Converium rejected the approach, saying that it is not in the interests of shareholders. Scor’s approach follows last year’s acquisition by Swiss Re of General Electric‘s Insurance Solution unit for $7.4 billion. Axa, Europe’s second-largest insurer, in June agreed to sell its Axa Re reinsurance unit to a group of investors. Reinsurers help primary insurers like Allianz shoulder risks for clients.

abstract: The 3i Group is in talks to buy Enterpise, a British pipe-laying company, for 486 million pounds ($949 million), or 605 pence a share, the company’s independent directors said in a statement Monday. Such an offer would represent a 30 percent premium to Enterprise’s stock price on Nov. 7, and a 5.2 percent premium over an offer made on Jan. 12, which was rejected as too low by the company’s directors.

abstract: Qatar is in talks to buy a 10 percent stake in EADS, the parent company of Airbus, the country’s foreign minister told news services Monday. Foreign Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabr al-Thani, who heads the $40 billion Qatar Investment Authority, told Bloomberg News that he was interested if the stake was “at the right value,” though he declined to say how much the authority would invest or from whom it would buy the stake.

abstract: Several things have emerged in the wake of the DaimlerChrysler drama. Talk that the German-American car maker may spin off or sell its troubled Chrysler unit has driven the company’s stock to highs last seen six years ago. Even as analysts criticize an acquisition of Chrysler as costly, thanks to healthcare liabilities and a poor product lineup, several suitors remain interested. And a report in The Detroit News suggests that General Motors‘ negotiations over Chrysler have been going on for some time.

abstract: ONLINE MARKET HEATS UP The big three third-party online travel-booking sites, Expedia, Orbitz and Travelocity, dropped slightly over all in customer-satisfaction ratings last year. The reason is that individual airline and hotel online sites, and other travel search sites like Kayak and SideStep, competed more aggressively for bookings, according to the annual American Customer Satisfaction Index, to be released today by the University of Michigan and the research company ForeSee Results. Of the three big sites, Expedia had the highest score, 78, a slight drop from 2005. Orbitz’s score was 75, up one point from 2005, and Travelocity’s was 74, down from 75 in 2005.

abstract: Panmure Gordon, the British investment bank, confirmed on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy Think Equity Partners, a United States investment bank specializing in telecommunications, media and technology, in a deal worth about $62 million. abstract: Just months after the Italian infrastructure minister, Antonio Di Pietro, blocked a Spanish company from buying the largest toll road company in Italy, he indicated Monday that he would not block Spanish acquisition of a large stake in Telecom Italia. abstract: Vulcan Materials, the nation’s biggest producer of highway construction materials, will acquire Florida Rock Industries for $4.6 billion to add concrete-making capability in the Southeast. Florida Rock shareholders will receive cash and stock valued at $68.03 a share, 45 percent higher than the closing price on Friday, Birmingham, Ala.-based Vulcan said Monday. The payment will be 70 percent in cash, it said.

abstract: Sberbank, Russia’s largest savings bank, was tallying the final orders on Monday from investors seeking entry to its $12 billion share sale, a deal that could become the biggest offering in Russian corporate history. The Financial Times reported that Sberbank’s supervisory board would convene on Wednesday to decide pricing for the domestic offering of up to 3.5 million new shares. Sberbank management has so far sent conflicting signals on how it wants to price the issue, throwing the stock price into turmoil.

Sberbank management has so far sent conflicting signals on how it wants to price the issue, throwing the stock price into turmoil.

headline.main: Russian Bank Closes in on $12 Billion Offering

abstract: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts said it refinanced its debt in a $160 million deal that should cut the company’s interest costs. The company, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., said it had borrowed $110 million to repay an existing $107 million balance on its existing credit deal, plus costs associated with the transaction. In addition, the company opened a $50 million revolving credit line.

abstract: India’s Bharti Enterprises of India plans to invest up to $2.5 billion to set up a nationwide chain of supermarkets and retail shops in partnership with  Wal-Mart, a top executive at the Indian company said. The investment will be spread over the next eight years and create jobs for about 60,000 people, Bharti’s joint managing director, Rajan B. Mittal, told reporters Monday. “The company has planned an investment of $2 billion to $2.5 billion by 2015,” Mr. Mittal said.

abstract: Start-ups are no longer a rare species in Europe. Moreover, many of Europe’s new entrepreneurs are returning from the United States, where they learned the start-up culture in Silicon Valley and Route 128 around Boston. After the dot-com bust, the number of European start-ups in the computer and telecommunications sectors began growing again in 2003, according to the Center for European Economic Research, in Mannheim, Germany. And venture capital is pouring into start-ups, attracting about $970 million last year, the highest level since the dot-com boom in 2000.

headline.main: Exporting Silicon Valley’s Lessons to Europe

abstract: When Bank of America announced its $35 billion acquisition of MBNA in summer 2005, many people questioned whether it would work. MBNA, a stand-alone credit-card giant, took pride in its fast-paced and entrepreneurial spirit, its freewheeling spending and a secretive corporate culture that seemed more like a cult. So far, Bank of America, the acquisition-hungry giant, has let that stand, though it was not easy.

So far, Bank of America, the acquisition-hungry giant, has let that stand, though it was not easy.

headline.main: A Clash of Cultures, Averted

abstract: The Yellow Pages Group said it would will pay 330 million Canadian dollars ($283 million) to acquire full ownership of Aliant Directory Services, an Atlantic Canadian telephone pages directory company partly owned by Yellow Pages of Montreal. the Yellow Pages Group, Canada’s dominant telephone directories publisher, said Monday it had signed a memorandum of understanding to acquire the Aliant directory business, which is owned 87.14 percent by the Halifax-based Bell Aliant Regional Communications Income Fund and the rest by Yellow Pages Income Fund.
lead_paragraph: The Yellow Pages Group said it would will pay 330 million Canadian dollars ($283 million) to acquire full ownership of Aliant Directory Services, an Atlantic Canadian telephone pages directory company partly owned by Yellow Pages of Montreal. the Yellow Pages Group, Canada’s dominant telephone directories publisher, said Monday it had signed a memorandum of understanding to acquire the Aliant directory business, which is owned 87.14 percent by the Halifax-based Bell Aliant Regional Communications Income Fund and the rest by Yellow Pages Income Fund.

abstract: After Sirius and XM, the United States’ two satellite radio services, announced plans Monday to merge in a $13 billion deal, speculation quickly turned to how regulators would react to such a combination. The proposal brought immediate comparisons to the proposed merger of satellite television broadcasters EchoStar and DirecTV, which regulators rejected four years ago. But the chief executive of Sirius, Mel Karmazin, wasted no time asserting that this was completely different, because those two firms had only one chief rival, cable television.
lead_paragraph: After Sirius and XM, the United States’ two satellite radio services, announced plans Monday to merge in a $13 billion deal, speculation quickly turned to how regulators would react to such a combination. The proposal brought immediate comparisons to the proposed merger of satellite television broadcasters EchoStar and DirecTV, which regulators rejected four years ago. But the chief executive of Sirius, Mel Karmazin, wasted no time asserting that this was completely different, because those two firms had only one chief rival, cable television.

headline.main: Satellite Radio Deal Puts Focus on Regulators

abstract: Shire, Britain’s third-largest drugmaker, agreed to buy New River Pharmaceuticals of Radford, Va., for $2.6 billion to gain the rights to the attention-deficit drug Vyvanse. Shire, which makes a competing drug, Adderall XR, said it would pay $64 a share, a 9.7 percent premium to the New River’s closing price on Friday. Shire plans to raise $800 million in a share sale to fund the acquisition.

abstract: Adam Chinn, a partner at the law firm Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, who focused on financial-services mergers and executive compensation issues, is joining Centerview Partners, a recently opened investment banking boutique, as a founding partner, Centerview said. A partner at Wachtell Lipton since 1994, Mr. Chinn has helped many top executives beef up their employment agreements, giving rise to the term “the Chinn-up.” Centerview was founded last year by Stephen Crawford, formerly co-president of Morgan Stanley, Blair Effron, formerly vice chairman at UBS, and Robert Pruzan, formerly president of Wasserstein Perella.
lead_paragraph: Adam Chinn, a partner at the law firm Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, who focused on financial-services mergers and executive compensation issues, is joining Centerview Partners, a recently opened investment banking boutique, as a founding partner, Centerview said. abstract: If there was ever a merger designed to reduce costly competition, the satellite radio merger is it.

abstract: Is it time to cash out of London commercial real estate? Prognosticators can mull over the latest pair of high-profile sales in that red-hot market. According to The Financial Times, Tishman Speyer‘s latest sale is Goldman Sachs‘ headquarters on Fleet Street, currently priced at 350 million pounds ($685 million), up from the 280 million pounds it paid in 2005. Separately, Merrill Lynch is considering up to four bids for its European headquarters, to the tune of 600 million pounds.

abstract: Private equity firms have reportedly been circling the British supermarket chain J. Sainsbury, considering a takeover bid that would be Europe’s biggest leveraged buyout ever. Could supermarkets in the United States draw a similar crowd? Perhaps, Bear Stearns analyst Robert Summers suggests. Among American food and drug retailers, the major grocery chains are the likeliest candidates for a buyout, he wrote in a note Tuesday. By his math, however, only Kroger — the No. 1 chain in the United States — could provide enough profit to a potential buyer, without making “heroic assumptions” in terms of margins or exit multiples.
lead_paragraph: Private equity firms have reportedly been circling the British supermarket chain J. Sainsbury, considering a takeover bid that would be Europe’s biggest leveraged buyout ever. Could supermarkets in the United States draw a similar crowd? Perhaps, Bear Stearns analyst Robert Summers suggests. Among American food and drug retailers, the major grocery chains are the likeliest candidates for a buyout, he wrote in a note Tuesday. By his math, however, only Kroger — the No. 1 chain in the United States — could provide enough profit to a potential buyer, without making “heroic assumptions” in terms of margins or exit multiples.

headline.main: Should Buyout Firms Check Out Kroger?

abstract: There is nothing like a legal fight to draw out the inner workings of the normally secretive dealmaking process. TheStreet.com’s Melissa Davis examined the court filings in the battle over Caremark Rx‘s proposed merger with drugstore chain CVS and came up with two “major revelations” that seemed especially disturbing to the judge in the case. Express Scripts, which has made a hostile offer for Caremark, wants the court to block the CVS merger. The judge expects to rule on the matter next week.

abstract: Enterprise, a British support services group that rejected a 528 million pound ($1.04 billion) offer from 3i Group in January, has gone back to the negotiating table. abstract: Providence Equity Partners, a private company that focuses on media and communications, said Wednesday that it had raised $12 billion for its sixth buyout fund. abstract: Citigroup‘s property unit said it had raised $1.29 billion for its first fund to invest in real estate and related assets in the Asia-Pacific region, with a focus on China and India. Citigroup and its investment professionals committed $200 million to the fund, CPI Capital Partners Asia Pacific LP, the bank said. The fund will be managed by a team of more than 25 employees based in Hong Kong and led by managing director David Schaefer. About 40 percent of the fund has been invested or pledged already.

abstract: SV Life Sciences has closed its fourth investment fund with $572 million in committed capital, signaling optimism about opportunities ahead after a strong year of M&A exits in 2006. The $572 million in commitments eclipses by 43 percent the $402 million SV pulled in for its third fund. The firm plans to continue to make early-stage investments in biotech and medical devices and leveraged buyouts of healthcare services ranging from $5 million to $25 million.

abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Braintree Energy on Tuesday of bilking investors of $9 million by using high-pressure sales tactics and promises of extraordinary returns to induce them to buy shares in unproductive oil and gas projects. The S.E.C. also said Howard Graham, who ran Braintree Energy, “misappropriated” up to $3 million of proceeds from investors for his personal use.

abstract: American Skiing has agreed to sell the Killington and Pico ski resorts in Vermont for $83.5 million, four days after disclosing the sale of Mount Snow in southern Vermont and the Attitash ski area in New Hampshire. The resorts were sold to SP Land, a Dallas real estate investor, and Powdr, a resort company based in Utah and the sales include all of the real estate owned by Killington and Pico. SP Land will assume about $5 million in debt as part of the purchase.

abstract: Federal prosecutors investigating the backdating of stock options are bumping up against a legal deadline that may affect when they file charges and what charges they bring. Under federal law, prosecutors typically have five years to bring charges of securities fraud. But, notes The San Jose Mercury News, for many of the backdating cases, that time window could be closing, because the misdating of stock options largely ended in 2002 thanks to new regulations.

abstract: US Airways‘ chief executive, W. Douglas Parker, was sentenced to one day in jail and a fine of $1,646 after pleading guilty to driving under the influence. Mr. Parker was pulled over for speeding Jan. 31, the same day that US Airways dropped its $10 billion bid for Delta Air Lines. Mr. Parker, who will serve his 24 hours behind bars on March 15, pleaded guilty Tuesday to the DUI against the advice of his attorney, the airline said.

headline.main: US Airways Chief Sentenced for DUI

abstract: As lawmakers in the United States and Europe mull ways to bring greater transparency to the largely unregulated hedge fund industry, Canada is moving ahead with its own plans to force hedge fund managers to register with regulators and pass tests to prove their proficiency. Under the plan, hedge fund managers and sales staff also would have to clear a background check, the Canadian Securities Administrators said at a Toronto news conference Tuesday.

abstract: Warner Music on Tuesday confirmed that it has restarted talks with Britain’s EMI Group about a possible merger of the two music labels, adding that the Independent Music Publishers and Labels Association had agreed to support such a deal before the European Commission. Warner, which has tried unsuccessfully to combine with EMI several times over the last few years, said it believes the agreement with the association improves its chances of getting regulatory approval. The New York Post said the deal was the first time that the group, known as Impala, has worked in tandem with a major label.

abstract: DaimlerChrysler‘s potentially pending auction of the Chrysler Group may field bids from a slew of buyers. The Renault–Nissan alliance, however, will not be among them, despite its interest in taking on a North American partner. A Nissan spokeswoman said Wednesday that the two car makers are focusing on righting their own finances, a task that would be difficult if the companies were saddled with ailing Chrysler. Last year, Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of both companies, entered talks with General Motors about a potential alliance, but none was formed.

abstract: Sapporo, Japan’s third-largest brewer, may resort to a management buyout to stymie Steel Partners, a hedge fund based in the United States that is trying to take over the company, the Kyodo news agency reported Wednesday. Previous reports said that Sapporo was in talks with its rivals, Asahi Breweries or Kirin Brewery, about a possible joint venture to thwart Steel Partners, which has said it mightlaunch a tender offer to raise its stake in Sapporo to 66.6 percent from 18.6 percent.

abstract: Nearly a year ago, when DealBook posted this item on rising salaries for first-year associates at top law firms, we were flooded with comments, many describing the grueling hours that associates were often made to work. So we were intrigued to see Tuesday’s post on The Wall Street Journal’s Law Blog, inspired by an internal memo that recently made the rounds at Mayer, Brown, Rowe & Maw‘s New York office. From reading the memo, it appears that, though they may stay late in the evenings, the associates in Mayer Brown’s securitization practice are not always the earliest of risers.

abstract: There was time, not that long ago, when private equity firms did not even consider technology companies as potential buyout candidates. Tech companies often have unpredictable cash flows, making it difficult to cover the interest payments in a debt-funded takeover. They can also require huge capital expenditures, which means more investment front and lower returns down the line. Things have changed, however — consider last year’s hotly contested $18.8 billion deal for Freescale Semiconductor — so analysts at Citigroup took a look at which tech companies might draw buyout interest.

abstract: In a deal that will combine two leading retailers of natural and organic foods, Whole Foods Market said Wednesday it will buy Wild Oats Markets for $565 million in cash, its largest acquisition ever. Whole Foods has offered $18.50 per share for Wild Oats, whose largest shareholder is Yucaipa Companies, the investment firm controlled by supermarket mogul Ronald W. Burkle. Yucaipa, which holds a stake of about 18 percent in Wild Oats, has agreed to tender its shares in the offer, the companies said in a press release.

abstract: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, below, said he plans to take control of the nation’s diamond mines in response to allegations of smuggling and a diamond rush in the eastern district of Marange. Zimbabwe has two diamond mines, one known as Murowa, owned by Rio Tinto and RioZim, and the other as River Ranch, which is held by private investors. “Only government will mine diamonds,” Mr. Mugabe said in a televised interview on Tuesday. It is unclear whether Mr. Mugabe’s pronouncement will be made law, said David Murangari, chief executive of the Chamber of Mines, a business association that represents most mining companies in the country. Andrew Cranswick, chief executive of African Consolidated Resources, criticized the measure. “If the state takeover of diamond mines is passed into law, it will destroy diamond exploration in this country,” he said.

Andrew Cranswick, chief executive of African Consolidated Resources, criticized the measure. “If the state takeover of diamond mines is passed into law, it will destroy diamond exploration in this country,” he said.

abstract: Russia’s state savings bank, Sberbank, was poised to raise $8.8 billion in a secondary stock offering that closed on Wednesday, a government official said. The offering would be the second largest in Russian history, after that of the state-controlled oil company Rosneft, which raised $10.6 billion in an initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange in July.

abstract: NASD, the brokerage firm regulator, said Wednesday that it had fined Raymond James Financial $2.75 million for failing to supervise more than 1,100 branch managers nationwide, including one who urged an 84-year-old woman to put most of her money into a single aggressive mutual fund. According to NASD, Raymond James let branch managers supervise their own sales activities from April 2000 to September 2004 and failed to assess properly whether the investment advice was sound.
lead_paragraph: NASD, the brokerage firm regulator, said Wednesday that it had fined Raymond James Financial $2.75 million for failing to supervise more than 1,100 branch managers nationwide, including one who urged an 84-year-old woman to put most of her money into a single aggressive mutual fund. According to NASD, Raymond James let branch managers supervise their own sales activities from April 2000 to September 2004 and failed to assess properly whether the investment advice was sound.

headline.main: Raymond James Fined in Lack of Oversight

abstract: The government will not try to reinstate the fraud convictions of two former executives of Westar Energy, prosecutors said Wednesday. The United States attorney’s office in Topeka, Kan., said it would not ask an appeals court in Denver to reconsider its decision in January to reverse the convictions of the executives, David C. Wittig and Douglas T. Lake. The appeals court said that evidence at the trial did not justify the guilty verdicts.

headline.main: U.S. Won’t Seek to Restore Fraud Conviction of Ex-Westar Officials

abstract: A judge took the unusual step Wednesday of reversing a jury verdict, finding that the evidence did not support the conviction of a former New York Stock Exchange supervisor who once oversaw trading in General Electric stock.
lead_paragraph: A judge took the unusual step Wednesday of reversing a jury verdict, finding that the evidence did not support the conviction of a former New York Stock Exchange supervisor who once oversaw trading in General Electric stock.

headline.main: U.S. Judge Voids Guilty Verdict of Big Board Specialist in G.E.

abstract: Securities regulators have fined Veritas Software, a business software maker, $30 million to settle accusations that the company engaged in an assortment of accounting schemes in the years leading to its sale to Symantec in 2005. The civil penalty, disclosed Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, was announced four and a half years after regulators opened an inquiry into a deal that Veritas negotiated with AOL in 2000.

abstract: Citigroup may seek to take over its Japanese investment-banking venture with Nikko Cordial after an accounting scandal led to the resignation of six top Nikko executives, Bloomberg News reported. Nikko, Japan’s third-biggest securities firm, admitted to overstating earnings in 2004 and an outside panel found evidence of fraud. Furthermore, the Tokyo-based company, whose shares have dropped 19 percent since Dec. 15, may lose its stock-market listing.

headline.main: Citigroup May Take Nikko Matters into Its Own Hands

abstract: Central Parking, an owner and operator of parking lots, said Wednesday that it had accepted a takeover bid of about $733 million from a private equity consortium led by Kohlberg and Company. The deal with the consortium, which also includes Lubert-Adler and Chrysalis Capital Partners, values the parking and transportation services company at $22.53 a share, a 6 percent premium over its closing stock price on Tuesday.

abstract: Babcock & Brown, Australia’s second-biggest investment bank, said second-half profit increased 84 percent after the firm started new funds and earned more from managing property and energy assets. Net income rose to 188 million Australian dollars ($148 million) in the six months ended Dec. 31, from 102 million Australian dollars a year earlier, the Sydney-based company said Thursday.

abstract: Xinhua Finance Media, a provider of financial news and data on China’s markets, plans to raise as much as $371.5 million in a share offering in the United States to repay debt and finance acquisitions. The company plans to sell 23.1 million American depositary shares for $12 to $14 each and has applied to list them on the Nasdaq Stock Market under the symbol XFML, Shanghai-based Xinhua Finance Media said in a regulatory filing in the United States.

abstract: Rexel, the world’s biggest distributor of electrical equipment, filed initial public offering documents with the French regulator. The filing is the first step toward a share sale, the Paris-based company said in a statement Thursday. The offering comes two years after Rexel was purchased for 3.7 billion euros ($4.9 billion) by the buyout unit of Merrill Lynch and private-equity firms Clayton, Dubilier & Rice and Eurazeo.

abstract: Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman, a global law firm based in New York, has asked at least eight former partners to return a portion or all of last year’s earnings within 30 days, The Recorder reports. Most say they have no intention of paying back anything, even if it means going to court.

abstract: Morgan Stanley, deciding it wants a bigger piece of the pie, ended its joint venture in India with JM Financial. Morgan will pay $445 million for the seven-year-old venture’s business trading stocks on behalf of foreign and local institutions, while JM Financial will pay $20 million for the venture’s investment banking business.

headline.main: Morgan Stanley Poaches Rivals for Latin America Office

abstract: Friendship Dairies, a New York-area maker of cottage cheese and sour cream, is close to wrapping up an auction run by Houlihan Lokey Howard & Zukin, according to The Deal.com. Friendship’s annual revenue is around $90 million to $100 million, and its Ebitda is around $11 million, the report said. The company’s products, which it describes as all-natural, are a refrigerator-shelf staple in the Northeast and have made incursions farther south. Daisy Brand of Dallas, a 90-year-old, family-owned maker of sour cream, is among the interested buyers, The Deal said.

Daisy Brand of Dallas, a 90-year-old, family-owned maker of sour cream, is among the interested buyers, The Deal said.

headline.main: Friendship Dairies on the Block

abstract: A biofuel developer, Imperium Renewables, raised $113 million in new equity to build four biodiesel processing facilities in a deal that highlights a maturing financing market for alternative fuel development, The Deal reported. The new money brings in a slew of private equity and institutional investors to round out what will be the largest single investment round for a biodiesel fuel developer.

abstract: Even with the sale of more than $18 billion in assets of Equity Office Properties Trust, Blackstone Group does not appear to be done dealing. In the latest sell off of properties it acquired in the biggest leveraged buyout in history, Blackstone sold 24 properties in downtown Los Angeles and Orange County, Calif., to Maguire Properties for $2.88 billion.

abstract: The median valuation of venture-backed companies in the United States, before the capital infusion, climbed to $18.5 million in 2006, the highest level since 2000, Dow Jones VentureOne reported. Startups are getting higher values because the opportunities for a profitable exit through an initial public offering or a sale have improved, an analyst told The Red Herring. Some of the largest gains were among information technology companies, whose median valuation has doubled from 2003.
lead_paragraph: The median valuation of venture-backed companies in the United States, before the capital infusion, climbed to $18.5 million in 2006, the highest level since 2000, Dow Jones VentureOne reported. Startups are getting higher values because the opportunities for a profitable exit through an initial public offering or a sale have improved, an analyst told The Red Herring. Some of the largest gains were among information technology companies, whose median valuation has doubled from 2003.

headline.main: Startup Valuations Show Strong Growth

abstract: General Atlantic, the private equity firm, is considering an initial public offering of Xchanging, a British outsourcing and processing business that ranks as one of its largest European investments. Xchanging, which General Atlantic formed in 1998, has been in discussions with a number of investment banks about an I.P.O. on the London Stock Exchange that could value the group at about 500 million pounds, The Financial Times reported. However, the paper said, those plans could still unravel.

abstract: Dean Foods, which grew into the nation’s largest dairy producer through a steady stream of mergers and acquisitions, may be testing the waters again. When asked at an analysts’ conference Wednesday whether the company was planning to use its rich coffers for a dividend or an acquisition, Dean’s chief financial officer, Jack Callahan, indicated that the time for more deals was nigh.

headline.main: Dean Foods to Go Shopping

abstract: Cisco Systems said Wednesday it will spend $135 million in cash and options to buy Reactivity, a small company that makes equipment to help route XML Internet traffic. Reactivity’s equipment is designed to help companies more easily and quickly deploy XML (Extensible Markup Language), a standard for Web documents. The company, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., was founded in 1998 and has 56 employees.

abstract: It seems to be all litigation all the time for Conrad Black these days. In the latest courtroom battle, however, Mr. Black is the one doing the suing. The former head of the Hollinger media empire is demanding 11 million Canadian dollars ($9.5 million) in libel damages over a critical biography that depicts the fallen press baron as an overweight teenager from a loveless home who grows up to be a “criminal sociopath.”
lead_paragraph: It seems to be all litigation all the time for Conrad Black these days. In the latest courtroom battle, however, Mr. Black is the one doing the suing.
