headline.main: Conrad Black Sues Author of ‘Sadistic’ Biography

abstract: Exploration said Wednesday that it would acquire a Houston-based exploration and production company for $95.6 million in a cash and stock deal that would be the biggest transaction in the company’s history. The acquisition of privately held Output Exploration will double the San Antonio-based company’s proven reserves and boost its current oil and gas production by almost two-thirds.
lead_paragraph: Exploration said Wednesday that it would acquire a Houston-based exploration and production company for $95.6 million in a cash and stock deal that would be the biggest transaction in the company’s history. The acquisition of privately held Output Exploration will double the San Antonio-based company’s proven reserves and boost its current oil and gas production by almost two-thirds.

headline.main: Exploration Fires Up Deal for Output

abstract: NASA and Virgin Galactic on Wednesday signed an agreement to explore the possibility of working together to develop new spacesuits, hybrid rocket motors and other space technology. Under the two-year memorandum of understanding, neither the NASA Ames Research Center nor Virgin Galactic would have to pay fees or fund the exploratory collaboration.
lead_paragraph: NASA and Virgin Galactic on Wednesday signed an agreement to explore the possibility of working together to develop new spacesuits, hybrid rocket motors and other space technology. Under the two-year memorandum of understanding, neither the NASA Ames Research Center nor Virgin Galactic would have to pay fees or fund the exploratory collaboration.

headline.main: NASA Teams Up With Virgin Galactic

abstract: Reports that the London private equity shop 3i Group  is in exclusive talks with Australia’s Macquarie Bank about the sale of National Car Parks, a business it acquired from crosstown buyout rival Cinven just 18 months ago, has met with heated words on the evils of private equity. News of the possible flip stoked union anger as workers at National Car Parks went on strike in north London to protest the refusal of 3i to recognize the union.
lead_paragraph: Reports that the London private equity shop 3i Group  is in exclusive talks with Australia’s Macquarie Bank about the sale of National Car Parks, a business it acquired from crosstown buyout rival Cinven just 18 months ago, has met with heated words on the evils of private equity. News of the possible flip stoked union anger as workers at National Car Parks went on strike in north London to protest the refusal of 3i to recognize the union.

headline.main: Reports of a 3i British Flip Provokes Outrage

abstract: After stocking up on shares of Wild Oats Markets, Ronald W. Burkle is set to check out at a tidy profit. Whole Foods Market, the natural-foods grocer, agreed Wednesday to pay $565 million for Wild Oats, a smaller competitor whose largest shareholder is Mr. Burkle’s investment firm, Yucaipa. At $18.50 a share, Whole Foods’ offer values Yucaipa’s nearly 18 percent stake at about $94.4 million. Yucaipa paid about $54 million, net of commissions, for its 5.1 milion shares, regulatory filings show.

Yucaipa paid about $54 million, net of commissions, for its 5.1 milion shares, regulatory filings show.

headline.main: Ronald Burkle Harvests His Wild Oats

abstract: Amateur speculators bring real estate excess.
snippet: Amateur speculators bring real estate excess.
lead_paragraph: Tales of Florida real estate speculation gone wild used to feature stories of underwater lots and swindled northeners. But now, according to an article in Thursday’s Times by Christine Haughney and Vikas Bajaj, we have investors who knowingly signed up to finance homes they would then flip. They are stuck partially built houses, construction liens and little market for the homes.

headline.main: Speculation Unleashed

abstract: Amid profit warnings steming from mortgage troubles in the United States, HSBC has replaced its head of North American operations, the European bank said Thursday. The resignation of Bobby Mehta, the chief executive of HSBC North America and of HSBC Finance, was effective Feb. 15. He will be succeeded by Brendan McDonagh, who was appointed chief operating officer at HSBC Finance earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: Amid profit warnings steming from mortgage troubles in the United States, HSBC has replaced its head of North American operations, the European bank said Thursday. The resignation of Bobby Mehta, the chief executive of HSBC North America and of HSBC Finance, was effective Feb. 15. He will be succeeded by Brendan McDonagh, who was appointed chief operating officer at HSBC Finance earlier this month.

headline.main: HSBC Ousts Its North American Chief

abstract: ValueAct Capital has offered to buy Catalina Marketing for $32 a share, or about $1.5 billion, in an effort to restart the sale process that the company began in December. Catalina announced Thursday morning that it had received the bid, but the offer was actually disclosed Wednesday, shortly before the close of trading, in a regulatory filing by ValueAct, sending Catalina’s shares sharply higher. In a letter to Catalina’s board, ValueAct said it hoped it would flush out higher offers and argued that a special committee of Catalina’s directors had ended the sale process “prematurely.”
lead_paragraph: ValueAct Capital has offered to buy Catalina Marketing for $32 a share, or about $1.5 billion, in an effort to restart the sale process that the company began in December. In a letter to Catalina’s board, ValueAct said it hoped it would flush out higher offers and argued that a special committee of Catalina’s directors had ended the sale process “prematurely.”

headline.main: Hedge Fund Offers to Buy Catalina Marketing

headline.main: An Experiment in Virtual Living
headline.kicker: From the Desk of David Pogue

abstract: Private equity firms have been offering compensation on an unprecedented scale to the chief executives who run the once-public companies that they have bought out. Could that be why so many companies are choosing to go private these days? If, so, “we would have a more serious problem than I thought,” Representative Barney Frank recently said, “because that would be elevating the private interests of the C.E.O. above every other consideration.”

Could that be why so many companies are choosing to go private these days? If, so, “we would have a more serious problem than I thought,” Representative Barney Frank recently said, “because that would be elevating the private interests of the C.E.O. above every other consideration.”

headline.main: Going Private to Get a Raise?

abstract: In a sign of just how closely Washington plans to examine the proposed merger of XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Satellite Radio, the House Judiciary Committee announced Thursday that it had formed a special group — the Antitrust Task Force — to consider the deal, which would create a single provider of satellite radio in the United States (albeit one that must still contend with old-fashioned radio as well as portable digital-music devices). Still, some analysts say they believe the markets are being too pessimistic about the deal’s chances of winning regulatory approval.
lead_paragraph: In a sign of just how closely Washington plans to examine the proposed merger of XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Satellite Radio, the House Judiciary Committee announced Thursday that it had formed a special group — the Antitrust Task Force — to consider the deal, which would create a single provider of satellite radio in the United States (albeit one that must still contend with old-fashioned radio as well as portable digital-music devices). Still, some analysts say they believe the markets are being too pessimistic about the deal’s chances of winning regulatory approval.

headline.main: Congress Tunes Into Satellite Radio Merger

abstract: Samuel Zell has an answer for critics who argue that the $39 billion deal he made to sell his Equity Office Properties to the Blackstone Group could have been even more lucrative. DealBook suggested as much in its recent column in The New York Times, writing that while Mr. Zell “played the Blackstone Group and Vornado Realty Trust like two fiddles,” he also left money on the table when he accepted a higher breakup fee in return for Blackstone’s raised bid, because it limited Vornado’s ability to come back with an even bigger offer.

headline.main: Zell Defends His Dealmaking Prowess

abstract: Sony bought video-sharing Web site Grouper in August. Google picked up YouTube, the king of video sites, in October. Now comes a report that Microsoft has taken a look at Revver, yet another venture-backed video-sharing startup. CNET News.com reports that executives from Microsoft toured Revver’s Los Angeles headquarters last month to determine whether that company’s service could enhance Soapbox, Microsoft’s own, newly launched service.

abstract: A group of top United States regulators on Thursday recommended market discipline and risk awareness, rather than new regulations, as the best safeguards for the burgeoning hedge-fund industry. The conclusions, intended as guidelines, were part of a report published by the President’s Working Group on Financial Markets, which includes the Federal Reserve Board, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

The conclusions, intended as guidelines, were part of a report published by the President’s Working Group on Financial Markets, which includes the Federal Reserve Board, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

abstract: Chrysler’s chief executive indicated it might be weeks or months before the automaker’s future can be determined.

lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, Feb. 22 — One week after DaimlerChrysler signaled its plans to put the Chrysler Group on the auction block, the company indicated on Thursday that it might be weeks or months before the future of the ailing American automaker can be determined.

headline.main: Watchwords at Chrysler Are Hurry Up and Wait
headline.print_headline: Watchwords at Chrysler Are Hurry Up and Wait

abstract: Malcolm E. McVay, the former chief financial officer of the HealthSouth Corporation, avoided prison and was granted five years’ probation.

lead_paragraph: Malcolm E. McVay, the former chief financial officer of the HealthSouth Corporation, avoided prison yesterday and was granted five years’ probation, the same sentence that an appeals court threw out last year as too lenient.

abstract: After a call for a boycott from a Roman Catholic archbishop, hundreds of complaints and one lawsuit from customers, the Canadian phone company Telus abandoned a service that allowed cellphone customers to buy soft-core pornography. Telus, based in Vancouver, began offering pornography to its five million wireless customers along with more conventional downloads like music and ring tones last month. Jim Johannson, a spokesman for the company, said the decision to end the service was based in part on “customer feedback.” Mr. Johannson, however, did not rule out a change in policy. “We operate in a really, really competitive business,” he said. “In this environment, it’s very difficult to predict the future.”.

abstract: Malcolm E. McVay, the former chief financial officer of HealthSouth, avoided prison Thursday and was granted five years’ probation, the same sentence that an appeals court threw out last year as too lenient. Judge Inge P. Johnson imposed the sentence in Federal District Court in Birmingham, Ala., saying that Mr. McVay played a relatively small role in the $2.7 billion accounting fraud at the company. The government had asked for a 28-month term; he could have served nine years.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm E. McVay, the former chief financial officer of HealthSouth, avoided prison Thursday and was granted five years’ probation, the same sentence that an appeals court threw out last year as too lenient. The government had asked for a 28-month term; he could have served nine years.

headline.main: HealthSouth Official Avoids Prison Term

abstract: Scott Callon, a former banker at Morgan Stanley, has led the first successful shareholder revolt in Japan, blocking the takeover of Tokyo Kohtetsu by a rival steel producer, Osaka Steel, after arguing that it offered no incentive to investors. An investment fund, Ichigo Asset Management, started a rare proxy fight against what it saw as an unfair share-swap ratio for Tokyo Kohtetsu, a small but highly profitable maker of steel sheets and H-beams.

abstract: Getty Images, the No. 1 provider of stock and editorial photographs, said on Thursday that it planned to buy the celebrity photo distributor WireImage for $200 million and is in talks to acquire another rival, Jupitermedia. The acquisitions would help Getty expand its product offerings at a time that it faces competition from smaller rivals, especially in its royalty-free images business – photographs sold at a set price to clients like advertisers.

abstract: Gamco Investors, asset manager headed by Mario Gabelli, said Thursday that it had offered to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into mutual fund share trading and, as a result, has increased its legal and regulatory reserves by $3 million. The company, based in Rye, N.Y., had previously taken a $12 million charge against earnings as a result of talks with the agency, which it said began last June. It said it expected to settle with the S.E.C. “in the near future.”
lead_paragraph: Gamco Investors, asset manager headed by Mario Gabelli, said Thursday that it had offered to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into mutual fund share trading and, as a result, has increased its legal and regulatory reserves by $3 million. The company, based in Rye, N.Y., had previously taken a $12 million charge against earnings as a result of talks with the agency, which it said began last June. It said it expected to settle with the S.E.C. “in the near future.”

headline.main: Gamco Offers to Settle S.E.C. Inquiry

abstract: Carl C. Icahn is not afraid to shake things up at big, publicly traded companies. In the 1980’s, the billionaire financier was known as a “corporate raider”; these days “activist investor” is the preferred term. But in an interview in BusinessWeek, Mr. Icahn suggests that private equity firms are the new corporate raiders — and it does not seem intended as a compliment. Mr. Icahn takes issue with private equity firms’ habit of buying cash-rich companies from public shareholders, piling on debt and selling them later at a profit. “Cash is a great asset,” he told BusinessWeek. “But if private equity investors get their hands on it, they’ll reap the benefit instead of the shareholder.”
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn is not afraid to shake things up at big, publicly traded companies. In the 1980’s, the billionaire financier was known as a “corporate raider”; these days “activist investor” is the preferred term. But in an interview in BusinessWeek, Mr. Icahn suggests that private equity firms are the new corporate raiders — and it does not seem intended as a compliment. Mr. Icahn takes issue with private equity firms’ habit of buying cash-rich companies from public shareholders, piling on debt and selling them later at a profit. “Cash is a great asset,” he told BusinessWeek. “But if private equity investors get their hands on it, they’ll reap the benefit instead of the shareholder.”

headline.main: Icahn: Buyout Firms Are the Real Raiders

abstract: A $40 billion lawsuit filed by former Enron shareholders and investors alleging investment firms and banks played key roles in the company’s collapse will go to trial in April despite a pending appeals court decision on the case, a judge has ruled. U.S. District Judge Melinda Harmon denied efforts by Merrill Lynch, Credit Suisse First Boston and Barclays to delay the trial while the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals rules on whether the case can proceed as a class-action suit.

abstract: U.S. antitrust authorities said Thursday they approved plans by American International Group to buy the U.S. port facilities of state-owned Dubai Ports World. Officials completed their antitrust investigation of the deal without taking any action, the Federal Trade Commission said in a notice. DP World said in December it agreed to sell the facilities in New York, New Jersey, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Miami, Tampa and New Orleans to A.I.G.

abstract: Morgan Stanley has agreed to pay about C$460 million ($396 million) for a majority stake in a Montreal-based container-shipping operation, making its first venture into Canada. abstract: The chief executive of Capitalia, Matteo Arpe, on Thursday defeated an attempt by the chairman, Cesare Geronzi, to remove him, winning the backing of the Italian bank’s leading investors after a fight over the bank’s merger strategy. After issuing a public apology to Mr. Geronzi, Mr. Arpe received the support of Capitalia’s main investors at a meeting in Rome, according to a statement from a shareholders’ group that owns 31 percent of the bank. Capitalia directors had been scheduled to meet later Thursday to decide whether to oust Arpe.

abstract: A ruling last week that ordered Bear Stearns to pay almost $160 million to investors in a hedge fund has inspired true fear on Wall Street, The New York Times’s Jenny Anderson reports. For banks, servicing hedge funds is a business so lucrative that it makes the go-go years of bringing technology companies public look quaint. For one, hedge funds do billions of dollars of business in multiple parts of the bank, while many technology companies promptly evaporated after going public.

abstract: Guidelines for safeguarding the hedge fund industry released yesterday by the Bush administration drew applause from much of Wall Street for their laissez-faire approach. A combination of common sense and market forces should be enough to keep this trillion-dollar-plus asset class from disrupting markets or decimating workers’ pensions, the report suggested. But there was criticism from some lawmakers and industry observers — as well as the attorney general of Connecticut, home to many of the biggest hedge funds — who complained the report’s recommendations were too weak.

abstract: As grimly illustrated by a Barron’s cover story last November — the one headlined “Death on the Floor,” with the suit-wearing skeleton standing in the middle of the New York Stock Exchange — these are perilous times for stock specialists. Specialists manage the buying and selling of particular stocks on the trading floor, but the rise of electronic trading has greatly cut into their business. Now, CNBC reports that the heads of major specialist firms recently met with John Thain, the chief of NYSE Group, which owns the New York Stock Exchange, and gave him an ultimatum, threatening to leave the business altogether unless he helps them out.

abstract: Ericsson, the world’s largest maker of wireless network gear, made a 9.8 billion-kronor ($1.4 billion) cash bid for Norway’s Tandberg Television, topping a rival offer by the Arris Group. Ericsson, based in Stockholm, is bidding 106 Norwegian kroner for each share of Tandberg TV,which boasts more than a quarter of the global market for video processing. Arris offered 96 kroner in cash and stock on Jan. 15. Tandberg Television’s stock rose 11 percent.

abstract: JPMorgan Chase will resume onshore equity broking services in Pakistan after an absence of five years to gain a share of a stock market that has grown 10-fold since 2001. The move underscores a rebound in emerging markets, which have recovered since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in the United States “There is more liquidity and the market capitalization has gone up,” Reza Rahim, a senior country officer, told Bloomberg News. “The Pakistan market has cheaper multiples compared with other emerging markets.”
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase will resume onshore equity broking services in Pakistan after an absence of five years to gain a share of a stock market that has grown 10-fold since 2001. abstract: Compensation for the chieftains of international investment banks is all relative, it seems. abstract: China Agri-Industries Holdings, a unit of China’s largest grain trader, may raise as much as 2.6 billion Hong Kong dollars ($332 million) in an initial public offering in Hong Kong, Bloomberg News reported. The unit of Hong Kong-traded Cofco International Ltd. will sell 697.8 million new shares, equal to a 20 percent stake, Bloomberg said. The shares are being offered at between 3.10 and 3.72 Hong Kong dollars each, Cofco said in a release Monday.

abstract: Sodexho Alliance, the world’s second-largest caterer, denied a report in La Lettre de L’Expansion that it plans a $5 billion bid for the United States real-estate broker Jones Lang LaSalle. The report is “false” and contains “wrong information,” a spokeswoman for Sodexho told Bloomberg News. According to the report, the caterer has hired Lazard to advise on the offer, which would take place this year and be financed with a $1 billion sale of debt and stock. Chicago-based Jones Lang, the world’s second-largest commercial real-estate broker, has a market value of about $4 billion.

abstract: The auction for preteen trinket retailer Claire’s Stores appears to be stumbling after several private-equity firms dropped out ahead of the deadline for final bids Wednesday, according to The New York Post. abstract: Caremark Rx, responding to a court ruling on Friday that it must provide more information on its proposed merger with CVS, delayed a shareholder vote by a week and assured shareholders Saturday they had the right to seek a court’s intervention if they are concerned about CVS’s offer for the pharmacy benefits manager. Caremark also sent notice that $35 million in payments to its investment bankers are contingent on their favorable recommendations about the merger with CVS, the nation’s largest retail pharmacy chain.

abstract: Being the world’s largest leveraged buyout is a fleeting honor these days. Last year’s acquisition of the hospital chain HCA held the title for a few months, only to be upstaged by the Blackstone Group‘s deal to buy Equity Office Properties Trust, the office landlord. That transaction, completed just a few weeks ago, now takes a backseat to the proposed takeover of TXU, led by the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group.

abstract: Talk that Microsoft might (or at least, should) acquire Yahoo has been going on for months. On Monday, TheStreet.com’s Vishesh Kumar joined the chorus, writing that Google‘s continued encroachment on Microsoft’s territory might force the software giant’s hand. Last week, Google, already the leader of the online search business, introduced an upgraded version of its applications suite, which directly targets Microsoft’s venerable Office product.

abstract: Hub International will be acquired by Apax Partners and the private equity arm of Morgan Stanley for about $1.8 billion, the insurance broker said Monday. The two firms will pay $40 a share, or a 16 percent premium over Hub’s closing price Friday of $34.49. Under a go-shop provision in the agreement, Hub may solicit other proposals until March 19. The breakup fee is $21 million.

abstract: Just as investors were receiving news of TXU‘s record-setting buyout agreement, a report has stirred up rumors about an even larger one. Shares of Dow Chemical jumped more than 5 percent on Monday, hitting a new 52-week high, after a British tabloid reported over the weekend that private equity firms might be preparing a $54 billion takeover bid for the company. Several analysts expressed doubt that any deal was in the works, but trading in Dow Chemical’s stock was extremely heavy Monday, with volume of more than triple the daily average by early afternoon.

abstract: There is little question that the comments allegedly made by Aaron Charney’s boss at the law firm Sullivan & Cromwell — if he made them — were rude and juvenile. abstract: Chalk up another win for Carl C. Icahn. Under pressure from the activist investor, the diversified holding company Temple-Inland announced Monday that it would spin off its real estate and financial services units and timberlands. Temple-Inland will instead focus on its packaging and building products, with proceeds from the sales to be distributed through a shareholder dividend and a debt restructuring, the company’s chief executive said in a conference call Monday morning.

abstract: Richard C. Breeden, the former top securities regulator in the United States, has been fairly tight-lipped for almost a year about his new career as an activist hedge fund investor. He declined to comment in January when The New York Times profiled his fledgling firm, Breeden Capital Management, and wrote about its proxy fight with restaurant chain Applebee’s International. Now, Mr. Breeden plans to open up — not to a group of fellow investors, but to a group of his former colleagues: lawyers.

abstract: As rumors swirl about who might buy Chrysler, Reuters asks a different question: Would a Chrysler-less Daimler-Benz be a candidate for a leveraged buyout? Since then, there has been speculation that hedge funds or private equity firms might try to buy the assets that remained after a Chrysler sale, including the prized Mercedes brand.

abstract: HIGH FLYING More people are going abroad in style. International premium travel  that is, first-class and business-class flying  grew 4.3 percent last year compared with 2005, according to the International Air Transport Association. Premium travel on the trans-Atlantic routes, which represent 16.1 percent of international premium traffic (the biggest proportion when travel within Europe is not counted) rose 7.8 percent in December compared with December 2005, and rose an overall 3.5 percent for the year. Premium traffic on Europe to Asia routes and all routes to the Middle East continued to grow in double digits, said the group, which represents 250 world airlines. Worldwide there were about 2.1 billion passengers in 2006, and 10.5 percent of them flew premium classes, the group said.

abstract: The NYSE Group said Monday that it had appointed Duncan L. Niederauer, currently a managing director at Goldman Sachs, president and co-chief operating officer effective April 9. Mr. Niederauer, who spent 22 years at Goldman Sachs, will be responsible for United States cash equities operations, including institutional and member firm client group sales and client services for both the New York Stock Exchange and its online securities exchange, NYSE Arca.

abstract: The forces of good apparently are not as much fun as the forces of evil. That, at least, seemed to be the lesson learned from the winners of career web site Vault.com’s Wall Street Video Resume Challenge for college students hoping to land a summer internship at a New York bank. The folks at Vault made it clear from the start that they weren’t holding a competition for the likes of Aleksey Vayner, the Yale student whose “Impossible Is Nothing” video resume became the butt of Wall Street jokes last fall.

abstract: There are risks in the $45 billion buyout of the Texas energy giant TXU, as there are in any large buyout, but for the Wall Street banks behind the deal, it could be even riskier, The New York Times notes. Wall Street banks have provided billions of dollars to finance takeovers in the last year, essentially serving as mortgage lenders to deal-hungry private equity firms, which are among the banks’ best-paying customers. Now the lenders have created a new type of loan that has them ponying up part of the down payment on these deals as well.

Now the lenders have created a new type of loan that has them ponying up part of the down payment on these deals as well.

abstract: Executives at Google‘s YouTube might want to take a page out of the playbook of Niklas Zennstrom and Janus Friis. This time, the duo behind the file-sharing service Kazaa and the Internet telephone service Skype are dotting their i’s and crossing their t’s when it comes to their latest venture, the web video start-up Joost. Revenue-sharing agreements have been signed. Licenses have been granted.

abstract: Microsoft‘s drive into the health care market is just getting under way, but the company signaled Monday that one important ingredient in its plan will be a specialized search engine tailored to deliver useful medical information to consumers. Microsoft is buying Medstory, a small start-up in Foster City, Calif., for an undisclosed amount. Its search software applies artificial intelligence techniques to medical and health information in medical journals, government documents and on the Internet.

abstract: Two former Citigroup executives won dismissal on Monday of a lawsuit in which the government accused them of keeping tens of millions of dollars for the bank’s asset management arm that should have gone to reduce mutual fund fees. The Securities and Exchange Commission claimed that Thomas W. Jones, the former chief executive of Citigroup Asset Management and Lewis E. Daidone, the former vice president of Smith Barney Management, kept the savings from a contract they had renegotiated with First Data Investment Services.

abstract: An accounting firm in Hong Kong made $2.7 million from illegal insider trades by hacking into computers to view press releases before they were published, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in a lawsuit filed on Monday. The S.E.C. sued the company, Blue Bottle, a Hong Kong-chartered firm that says it is based in London, and its chief executive, Matthew Charles Stokes. Blue Bottle made $2.7 million by hacking into computer systems shortly before the release of market-moving information, the S.E.C. said in a complaint filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: An accounting firm in Hong Kong made $2.7 million from illegal insider trades by hacking into computers to view press releases before they were published, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in a lawsuit filed on Monday. abstract: Halliburton, the oil field services provider, said on Monday that it would complete its separation from KBR by offering current stockholders the remaining 81 percent stake in KBR, its former subsidiary. Halliburton, once led by Vice President Dick Cheney, will offer its 135.6 million shares of KBR in exchange for its own stock. KBR is the largest American military contractor in Iraq. If the offer is not fully subscribed, any remaining KBR shares will be given to stockholders as a special dividend on a pro rata basis, Halliburton, which is based in Houston, said.
lead_paragraph: Halliburton, the oil field services provider, said on Monday that it would complete its separation from KBR by offering current stockholders the remaining 81 percent stake in KBR, its former subsidiary. If the offer is not fully subscribed, any remaining KBR shares will be given to stockholders as a special dividend on a pro rata basis, Halliburton, which is based in Houston, said.

headline.main: Halliburton to Complete Split With KBR

abstract: The Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group said on Monday that it had agreed to be acquired by a Los Angeles restaurant group for $79.5 million. But fans of its New York flagship restaurant need not fear: Its properties in New York will remain in the hands of its founder. Smith & Wollensky said that it had agreed to be acquired by the Patina Group of Los Angeles, which operates restaurants in New York, New Jersey, California and Las Vegas, for $9.25 a share, a premium of 12 percent over its closing share price on Friday. The bid topped an offer of $7.50 a share made last month by Landry’s Restaurants of Houston.

abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the drug maker, has been cleared of securities law violations in connection with its botched Plavix patent settlement last year, the company said on Monday in a regulatory filing. Christie, that a review found no violation of securities laws or breach of an earlier consent order the company had signed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

abstract: Volvo said on Tuesday it had agreed to buy the road development division of Ingersoll-Rand for $1.3 billion in cash to expand its construction equipment business, particularly in the United States. Volvo, which also makes trucks, buses and engines, expects the acquisition to save it about 600 million Swedish kronor ($85.2 million) — mainly within sales and distribution — over five years, the company said. The transaction is due to be completed in the second quarter, subject to regulatory approval.

abstract: Wal-Mart Stores, the world’s biggest retailer, struck a deal reportedly worth $1 billion to take over a Chinese rival by 2010, challenging Carrefour as the largest operator of super-centers in booming China. Wal-Mart said it had bought 35 percent of Bounteous, a deal that could trigger consolidation in China’s ferociously competitive $1 trillion retail market.

Prince III, is using his new hire to shore up investor support for himself, the appointment is not expected to produce startling change or immediate results.

abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire financier, has invested $50 million in a wireless content startup, Motricity. Motricity, which announced in August it plans to raise $75 million from investors, said it has completed the equity funding agreement with Mr. Icahn through “an affiliated company.” Mr. Icahn’s son, Brett Icahn, an investment analyst with New York-based Icahn Associates and a number of affiliated companies, will join Motricity’s board of directors as a result of the investment.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire financier, has invested $50 million in a wireless content startup, Motricity. headline.main: Icahn Goes Wireless With $50 Million

abstract: Mace Security International said on Monday that it had rejected a $3-a-share buyout offer from Kelly Capital Management but was holding talks for a possible higher offer from the investment firm. Mace asked investors for patience, saying that once its car-wash chain was liquidated, Mace would be in an “ideal position to grow its security business,” or pursue other opportunities. In recent years, Mace has tried to grow its surveillance and security businesses, which include the Mace pepper spray. The security business generates about $23.5 million a year in sales.

abstract: Red umbrella in hand, St. Paul Travelers has officially changed identities. The St. Paul-based insurer announced Monday that it would begin trading Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange under its new name, The Travelers Cos., and under a new ticker symbol. The firm also closed on its previously announced agreement to reacquire the red umbrella trademark from Citigroup.

abstract: Richard S. Fuld Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the brokerage firm Lehman Brothers Holdings, made $40.6 million in compensation last year after the company reported near-record profits, according to a regulatory filing on Monday. Mr. Fuld made a salary of $750,000 and a bonus of $6.24 million, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

abstract: The Conference Board, a business research and consulting group that publishes some of the nation’s leading economic surveys, has selected Jonathan Spector, a vice dean at the Wharton School, as its chief executive. Mr. Spector, 50, will succeed Richard E. Cavanagh, former executive dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, who has led the group since 1995. Mr. Cavanaugh announced last March that he was retiring. The selection of Mr. Spector, which is to be announced Monday by the Conference Board’s trustees, came after a yearlong search in which about 250 candidates were evaluated.

headline.main: A Wharton Dean Is Named to Lead the Conference Board

abstract: Another seasoned banker is set to leave Wall Street for Washington. The Bush administration will soon announce that Tim Ryan, a J.P. Morgan Chase vice chairman, will be the Treasury department’s next under-secretary for international affairs, The Financial Times reported Tuesday. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Ryan, who currently serves as the bank’s vice chairman of financial institutions and governments, will replace Tim Adams, who announced his desire to retire by the summer.

abstract: On the tail of a landmark deal with a Chinese retailer, Wal-Mart may be trying to sew up a prominent position in another emerging market. abstract: Many business leaders have complained about the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and other measures passed in reaction to the scandals at Enron and WorldCom. Advocates for these reforms say they were needed to cut down on corporate fraud, but critics argue that they created onerous costs for companies and new risks — not the least of which is the potential for being sent to prison — for their executives.
lead_paragraph: Many business leaders have complained about the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and other measures passed in reaction to the scandals at Enron and WorldCom. abstract: Magna International, the Canadian auto parts maker, said that fourth-quarter profit fell 65 percent because of lower profit margins and one-time charges. It cut its quarterly dividend to increase cash on hand. Net income was $29 million, or 26 cents a share, down from $83 million, or 75 cents a share, a year earlier, Magna said. Sales rose 8.7 percent, to $6.4 billion. The company, cut its quarterly divided in half, to 19 cents a share, adding $84 million in cash to the $1.9 billion the company had on hand at the end of 2006. Excluding one-time items, Magna earned 99 cents a share, missing the $1.16 a share that was expected by Wall Street analysts.

abstract: The former top lawyer of McAfee was charged on Tuesday with stock options tampering that muddied the finances of the computer security software maker. A federal grand jury indicted the lawyer, Kent Roberts, nine months after McAfee fired him as its general counsel for “improper” handling of stock options issued in 2000. The indictment includes seven criminal counts of fraud, accusing Mr. Roberts of deceiving investors by filing false statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission and falsifying McAfee’s books.

abstract: Blockbuster, which on Tuesday reported a 28 percent decline in its fourth-quarter earnings, said it was trying to resolve a dispute with its chairman and chief executive, John F. Antioco, over his 2006 bonus. On Jan. 25, the board of the movie rental company awarded Mr. Antioco a bonus of $2.28 million, on top of his 2006 salary and deferred compensation of about $2.5 million. But according to a statement in the company’s earnings report, Mr. Antioco claims he is entitled to a total of $10.15 million.

abstract: In yet another twist in the ongoing saga of E.ON‘s attempt to buy its Spanish rival Endesa, Enel, Italy’s biggest power company, said on Wednesday that it might increase its stake in Endesa to almost 25 percent. In a move that threatens to thwart E.ON’s yearlong, 41 billion euro takeover bid for Endesa, the Italian utility said onTuesday it had acquired 9.99 percent of Endesa for about 4.13 billion euros ($5.47 billion). Enel said Wednesday it is considering raising the stake to as much as 24.99 percent.

Enel said Wednesday it is considering raising the stake to as much as 24.99 percent.

headline.main: E.ON Faces an 11th Hour Upset in Deal for Endesa

abstract: Volkswagen has increased its stake in the German truck maker MAN to 29.9 percent in a move that Volkswagen said Tuesday could help pave the way for a merger between MAN and the Swedish company Scania. Volkswagen, the largest European carmaker, held about 20 percent of MAN before increasing its holding Monday. It is also the biggest shareholder in Scania, with 18.7 percent of the capital and 34 percent of the voting rights.

It is also the biggest shareholder in Scania, with 18.7 percent of the capital and 34 percent of the voting rights.

headline.main: By Raising Man Stake, Volkswagen May Jump-Start Merger Talks

abstract: China Pacific, a life insurer, has struck a crucial shareholder agreement with the Carlyle Group, paving the way for a $1 billion initial public offering of China Pacific this year, The Financial Times reported. Preparation for the listing of state-owned China Pacific has been on hold for several months pending talks with a Carlyle-led consortium, which acquired a 25 percent stake in the group’s life insurance arm for $410 million in December 2005.

headline.main: China Pacific Clears Obstacle to I.P.O.

abstract: General Electric‘s chief executive, Jeffery Immelt, received $17.9 million in compensation last year, according to a company filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In a proxy statement detailing executive compensation, G.E. said Mr. Immelt’s payout included $3.3 million in salary, $5 million in bonus, $7.4 million in stock awards and options valued at $574,322. But, as the commercial says, that’s not all: Mr. Immelt’s payout also included other benefits – such as payments for life insurance, retirement plans and use of the company aircraft – valued at about $1.6 million.

But, as the commercial says, that’s not all: Mr. Immelt’s payout also included other benefits – such as payments for life insurance, retirement plans and use of the company aircraft – valued at about $1.6 million.

headline.main: G.E. Chief Gets $17.9 Million, Plus Time on the Jet

abstract: EGL‘s chairman said Wednesday that he had found a new group of investors, including Centerbridge Partners and the Woodbridge Company, to participate in his offer to take the transportation company private. His previous buyout partner, General Atlantic, withdrew from the original deal, after it was announced in January.
lead_paragraph: EGL‘s chairman said Wednesday that he had found a new group of investors, including Centerbridge Partners and the Woodbridge Company, to participate in his offer to take the transportation company private. His previous buyout partner, General Atlantic, withdrew from the original deal, after it was announced in January.

headline.main: EGL Chairman Finds New Buyout Backers

abstract: As major stock indexes in Asia and Europe continued to slide on Wednesday, there were fears that the choppy markets would cool the recent deal-making frenzy. Volatility is the enemy of deal negotiations, and many Wall Street firms have been banking on China, where the recent stock slide was most severe, for much of their growth potential.
lead_paragraph: As major stock indexes in Asia and Europe continued to slide on Wednesday, there were fears that the choppy markets would cool the recent deal-making frenzy. Volatility is the enemy of deal negotiations, and many Wall Street firms have been banking on China, where the recent stock slide was most severe, for much of their growth potential.

headline.main: Will Market Jitters Chill Deal-Making?

abstract: Martin Peretz, who has been a part owner of The New Republic for more than three decades, has given up his share of the magazine, selling his interest to CanWest Global Communications, which now assumes full control. Mr. Peretz is to remain as editor in chief. CanWest, which bought a 30 percent interest in the magazine last year, announced Tuesday that a subsidiary, CanWest Media Works International, had acquired a 100 percent interest in The New Republic. Terms were not announced.
lead_paragraph: Martin Peretz, who has been a part owner of The New Republic for more than three decades, has given up his share of the magazine, selling his interest to CanWest Global Communications, which now assumes full control. Mr. Peretz is to remain as editor in chief. CanWest, which bought a 30 percent interest in the magazine last year, announced Tuesday that a subsidiary, CanWest Media Works International, had acquired a 100 percent interest in The New Republic. Terms were not announced.

headline.main: New Republic’s Top Editor Sells His Stake to CanWest

abstract: The private investor group that is acquiring Univision Communications said Tuesday that it had named Joe Uva, president and chief executive of the ad-buying firm OMD Worldwide, to become chief executive when the acquisition closes. Mr. Uva, 51, will succeed A. Jerrold Perenchio, 76, Univision’s longtime chairman and chief executive, on April 1, the investor group, Broadcasting Media Partners, said. The terms of Mr. Uva’s contract were not disclosed. He will remain based in New York when he takes control of Univision, which is based in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The private investor group that is acquiring Univision Communications said Tuesday that it had named Joe Uva, president and chief executive of the ad-buying firm OMD Worldwide, to become chief executive when the acquisition closes. The terms of Mr. Uva’s contract were not disclosed. He will remain based in New York when he takes control of Univision, which is based in Los Angeles.

headline.main: Univision Gets a New Chief

abstract: Vantage Media, which provides search-based Web marketing services, said Wednesday it had completed a $70 million preferred financing round led by Montgomery & Company, the investment bank that helped sell the social-networking site MySpace to the News Corporation. Vantage also hired a new chief executive, Steve Jillings, who told Reuters that an initial public offering was possible in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Vantage Media, which provides search-based Web marketing services, said Wednesday it had completed a $70 million preferred financing round led by Montgomery & Company, the investment bank that helped sell the social-networking site MySpace to the News Corporation. Vantage also hired a new chief executive, Steve Jillings, who told Reuters that an initial public offering was possible in 2008.

headline.main: Vantage Media Raises $70 Million

abstract: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the owner of the A.&P. and Food Emporium supermarket chains, said Tuesday that it was in talks to acquire Pathmark Stores for $652.5 million. Great Atlantic is offering Pathmark shareholders $12.50 a share in cash and stock, a 3.7 percent premium above Pathmark’s closing price Monday of $12.05 a share, if a deal is reached, Great Atlantic said.
lead_paragraph: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the owner of the A.&P. and Food Emporium supermarket chains, said Tuesday that it was in talks to acquire Pathmark Stores for $652.5 million. Great Atlantic is offering Pathmark shareholders $12.50 a share in cash and stock, a 3.7 percent premium above Pathmark’s closing price Monday of $12.05 a share, if a deal is reached, Great Atlantic said.

headline.main: A.&P. Goes Shopping for Pathmark

abstract: Days after a presidential commission recommended a hands-off approach to regulating hedge funds, the Treasury Department is defending its new guidelines against critics who say the new rules don’t go far enough, according to The Financial Times. Answering naysayers — who include several state attorneys general — Robert K. Steel, a deputy to Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., said that the President’s Working Group on Financial Markets would stand firm on its report’s recommendations.
lead_paragraph: Days after a presidential commission recommended a hands-off approach to regulating hedge funds, the Treasury Department is defending its new guidelines against critics who say the new rules don’t go far enough, according to The Financial Times. Answering naysayers — who include several state attorneys general — Robert K. Steel, a deputy to Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., said that the President’s Working Group on Financial Markets would stand firm on its report’s recommendations.

headline.main: Treasury Official Defends New Hedge Fund Guidelines

abstract: There is no bubble in the buyout business, David Rubenstein, the co-founder of the Carlyle Group, said Wednesday. But is it near the top of the cycle? Probably, he suggested. “There will be declines,” Mr. Rubenstein said Wednesday at the Super Return conference in Frankfurt. “We can’t continue like this forever.” His remarks were part of a speech called “Comparing Tech Bubble & Private Equity Today,” in which he examined whether the booming private-equity industry could be headed for a crash similar to what the technology sector suffered in 2000.
lead_paragraph: There is no bubble in the buyout business, David Rubenstein, the co-founder of the Carlyle Group, said Wednesday. But is it near the top of the cycle? headline.main: Buyout Chief: ‘We Can’t Continue Like This Forever’

abstract: Harvey Miller, the veteran corporate bankruptcy lawyer, is considering leaving the boutique investment bank Greenhill & Company, where he is vice chairman, The Deal reported. Mr. Miller declined to comment for the article, but The Deal, citing undisclosed sources, reported that he might return to the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges, whose high-powered bankruptcy practice he founded and led for 31 years.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Miller, the veteran corporate bankruptcy lawyer, is considering leaving the boutique investment bank Greenhill & Company, where he is vice chairman, The Deal reported. headline.main: Greenhill’s Miller Said to Consider Return to Law

abstract: Venture-backed Range Fuels will receive up to $76 million in funding from the Department of Energy to build a plant that produces ethanol from wood chips and forest residue. The funding is one of six grants the Energy Department announced Wednesday, all for the construction of cellulose-based ethanol plants, with a total value of up to $385 million.
lead_paragraph: Venture-backed Range Fuels will receive up to $76 million in funding from the Department of Energy to build a plant that produces ethanol from wood chips and forest residue. The funding is one of six grants the Energy Department announced Wednesday, all for the construction of cellulose-based ethanol plants, with a total value of up to $385 million.

headline.main: Range Fuels Gets U.S. Funding for Ethanol Plant

abstract: Wall Street and the financial press spent much of their day Wednesday looking for someone or something to blame for “The Glitch” — that seemed to be the preferred term — that caused trading delays Tuesday afternoon on the New York Stock Exchange, even as the market was plunging and the system that calculates the Dow Jones Industrial Average was having trouble keeping up with it all. The NYSE Group said it was “assessing the situation,” which raised questions about the exchange’s new hybrid market, a platform that combines electronic trading with old-fashioned floor trading.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street and the financial press spent much of their day Wednesday looking for someone or something to blame for “The Glitch” — that seemed to be the preferred term — that caused trading delays Tuesday afternoon on the New York Stock Exchange, even as the market was plunging and the system that calculates the Dow Jones Industrial Average was having trouble keeping up with it all. The NYSE Group said it was “assessing the situation,” which raised questions about the exchange’s new hybrid market, a platform that combines electronic trading with old-fashioned floor trading.

headline.main: After ‘The Glitch,’ the Wall Street Blame Game

abstract: The list of potential bidders for J Sainsbury may have grown to include another major British marque: Marks & Spencer. Stuart Rose, the chief executive of Marks & Spencer, Britain’s largest clothing store, said at a conference on Wednesday that he was mulling an offer for Sainsbury.
lead_paragraph: The list of potential bidders for J Sainsbury may have grown to include another major British marque: Marks & Spencer. Stuart Rose, the chief executive of Marks & Spencer, Britain’s largest clothing store, said at a conference on Wednesday that he was mulling an offer for Sainsbury.

headline.main: Marks & Spencer’s Chief Ponders Sainsbury Bid

abstract: In an effort to coordinate its international mergers and acquisitions advisory work, Deutsche Bank on Wednesday appointed two global co-heads for the division, as well as a host of regional staff changes. Most notable are the appointments of Tony Burgess and James Stynes to new roles that report directly to the firm’s head of global banking, Michael Cohrs.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to coordinate its international mergers and acquisitions advisory work, Deutsche Bank on Wednesday appointed two global co-heads for the division, as well as a host of regional staff changes. Most notable are the appointments of Tony Burgess and James Stynes to new roles that report directly to the firm’s head of global banking, Michael Cohrs.

headline.main: Deutsche Bank Reshuffles Its M&A Roster

abstract: A veteran technology analyst, Steven Milunovich, will become a New York-based partner at the Brunswick Group to help strengthen the public relations firm’s investor relations business, the company said Wednesday. Mr. Milunovich spent many years as a top-ranked computer hardware analyst and managing director at Merrill Lynch until he left the firm in 2005 to start his own hedge fund, Financial News reported. He returned to Merrill in early 2006.
lead_paragraph: A veteran technology analyst, Steven Milunovich, will become a New York-based partner at the Brunswick Group to help strengthen the public relations firm’s investor relations business, the company said Wednesday. He returned to Merrill in early 2006.

abstract: More delinquencies appear in sub-prime land
snippet: More delinquencies appear in sub-prime land
lead_paragraph: NovaStar Financial, the subprime lender, posts delinquency figures every month, but it does so by pool of mortgages that it sold to investors. That makes it relatively easy to track how any pool is going, but hard to figure out how they are all going.

headline.main: More Bad News at NovaStar

abstract: Two privately owned power plant operators servicing the Northeast will combine in a potentially $5 billion deal aimed at creating a 5,000-megawatt giant in the lucrative market. Astoria Generating, which services New York City, and EBG Holdings, which provides power to the Boston area, will form a new entity to be called U.S. Power Generating, the two companies said Wednesday.

Astoria Generating, which services New York City, and EBG Holdings, which provides power to the Boston area, will form a new entity to be called U.S. Power Generating, the two companies said Wednesday.

headline.main: Northeast Power Plant Operators to Merge
